PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax: Confectionery
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that the current discriminatory application of sales tax on confectionery at the rate of 20% is an unfair and unjust burden on this important manufacturing industry and your petitioners therefore pray that confectionery be treated in a similar fashion to all other foods, including snack foods, which are exempt from sales tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin,Mr Blunt,Mr Brumby,Mr Cowan,Mr Drummond,Mr Duffy,Mr Hodgman,Mr Morrison,Mr Rocher,Mr Saunderson and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that Regulations and an Ordinance before the Parliament amend the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulation and the Customs (Cinematograph and Films) Regulations and supersedes the ACT Objectionable Publications Ordinance in such a manner as to be harmful to society by removing from existing Commonwealth Law-
The power to prevent the importation and sale of hard core pornography (e.g. X- rated videos) and publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs;
The power to prevent the importation and sale of grossly obscene publications including those associated with blasphemy;
The power to require videos for non-commercial use to be registered by the Films Censorship Board before release from Customs.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should disallow the new Regulations and Ordinance and ensure:
That the Attorney-General enforce existing laws;
That the Censors more appropriately reflect reasonable and responsible community attitudes;
That further measures be taken in association with the States to protect Australians, particularly women and children, from exploitation;
That, because of the importance of this issue to the whole community a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Carlton and Mr Hodgman.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:

That, having received information from the Attorney-General's Department concerning the New Commonwealth Censorship Procedures for Publication. We are abhorred by the intent of the Government to change the already liberal Censorship Laws into such Laws as will open the doors to nearly complete license where publications are concerned.
We most strongly feel that in this way the Government would be intentionally instrumental in perverting the thoughts and actions of young and older Australians.
We therefore request the Government to abandon its 1983 decision to alter the A .C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinance forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in parliament assembled we the undersigned citizens of our community which is part of Australia wish to condemn the action of the present Government and urge it to abandon its 1983 decision to alter the A.C.T. classification of publications ordinance forthwith.

We believe this action of the present government will have a very demoralising influence upon the minds of the youth of our country. The evidences of these facts are proof in our society of today by the increasing acts of vandalism; rapes bashings and robbery. For the Government to ignore this fact with the present restrictions. To relax the laws on drugs and pornographic material would open the floodgates to lawlessness in out society. These young people are the citizens of our country tomorrow.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
That we the undersigned request the Government to abandon its 1983 decision to alter the A.C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinance forwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
That we are greatly disturbed by the attitudes and intentions of the Federal Government with respect to proposals in relations to the censorship laws.
That we find it abhorrent that it is intended to lift barriers which have previously prevented hard-core pornography and similarly offensive material from widespread distribution.
That we also note with disquiet the apparent lack of concern shown by the present Government for the moral health and well being of the Australian people.
That the Scriptures teach us that ''Righteousness exalts a nation, but sin is a reproach to any people.''
Your petitioners accordingly pray that the Government reconsider its policy and consequently abandon its 1983 decision to alter the A.C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinance forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:

(1) That we unreservedly oppose the Federal Government's proposals in relation to the censorship laws designed for the Australian Capital Territory; and further we oppose any such proposal on censorship laws becoming law in any State in Australia.
(2) That we consider it right and proper that the citizens of this nation be consulted, and their views and desires respected in the formulation of law in censorship and similar areas.

(3) That it is with alarm the proposed censorship laws are regarded by citizens living in a society based on christian ethics. In essence Australia is a Christian nation and our nation's laws must reflect and uphold our established values. Legislation which sanctions behaviour repugnant to Christians, is legislation not appropriate to Australia. Moreover, it is legislation which condones the destruction of the very fabric of our society. Legislation which promotes the degradation, abasement and exploitation of people, both young and old, and of our nation, is unacceptable.

(4) That we the undersigned request the Government to heed the points in this petition, and abandon its 1983 decision to alter the Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizen of Australia respectfully shows:
That as youth director of our local Community Baptist Church, it causes me great concern to learn of the governments intention to relax the control over hard drugs and pornographic material.

It also causes me great distress to learn that our Prime Minister, one who should be setting a standard and an example, says he is not concerned and regards those who are concerned over this issue as being stupid.

As a parent and one who works with young people I believe to relax such controls would be disastrous both to the minds and moral standards of our young people at large, even now it is becoming increasingly difficult to choose a film without an undue emphasis upon sex or violence, and if the government cannot see the effect of drugs on young lives then it must have its head in the sand.
If ever our youth needed good quality leadership it is today. By saying to them they can have whatever they want is a complete abdication of that leadership.
I cannot strongly enough voice my opposition so I the undersigned request the Government to abandon its 1983 decision to alter the A.C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinance forthwith.
And your petitioner as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights in the Soviet Union
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that the Soviet Union continues to violate human rights in Latvia. This is clearly demonstrated by the recent case of Janis Rozkalns, a practising Baptist who, on January 6, 1983, had his house forcibly entered into by K.G.B. agents searching for various religious publications. The K.G.B. confiscated 40 Bibles.
Mr Rozkalns was charged with 'anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda' and now faces a sentence of seven years deprivation of freedom plus five years internal exile.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled condemns the religious and human rights persecutions within the Soviet Union.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We petitioners of electors call on the Federal Labor Government to reject the demands of the Australian Medical Association and doctors who want to demolish Medicare.

We request the Government to implement Medicare in its original form. We believe that medical care and a proper health system are a basic social right and should not be a privilege available to a wealthy few.
We pray the Government does not succumb to the minority business interests opposing Medicare.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia , namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation 's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that 'the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: International Agreements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That international agreements, covenants, laws and the like cannot be imposed as laws in Australia by any government unless agreed to by the people by referendum as required by the Constitution.

That any existing legislation, or proposed legislation, based on any international agreement, covenant, law or the like such as Human Rights, Heritage Commission, Land Rights Acts, Race Relations Act, Sex Discrimination Act, etc., be repealed or suspended until agreed to by the people by referendum as required under the Constitution.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedom;
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action Hospitals, Doctors and Nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school 'community' provide an environment conducive to the development, including moral development of their children.
Deny to parents their rights to have their children enjoy single-sex sporting activities e.g., boys cricket team, boys football team, etc.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Parliament assembled should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to stop the commercial exploitation of the kangaroo.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House re-apply the ban on the export of kangaroo products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, loyal citizens of Australia firmly express our wish to have the traditional place of Her Majesty The Queen as Head of State retained in our national and constitutional and democratic affairs and institutions and also strongly advocate the retention of our present Australian National Flag, standing for historic and loyal links with the United Kingdom, the nation which founded our Australian way of life.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Humble Petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the overwhelming majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian National Flag.

2. That we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, unless such proposed change is first voted on by the people of Australia and passed by a majority of voters in a majority of States.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The Humble Petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That in November 1978 more than sixty-two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a Referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to Territorial or Local Government. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action nor legislate in respect of Territorial or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and request the Government to restore the Imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Military Establishment, Central Tablelands, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the undersigned Citizens of Australia showeth that:
We protest the proposed relocation of the Artillery and Infantry Schools from North Head, Singleton and Holsworthy to the Central Tablelands of New South Wales, and the Cobar district.

We humbly pray that the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, will ensure that the current investigation being carried out in the Central Tablelands is ceased forthwith and that no Military Establishment be located in the Central Tablelands of New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Chiropractic Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows :
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice and does nothing to reduce the high cost of health care in Australia.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Dr J. Martinick
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are patients, colleagues and friends of Dr J. Martinick.
That she is apparently being victimised by the Department of Health and the Federal Police regarding itemisation in 1983.
That at no time in the last year the Department of Health Liaison Officer or Investigator had approached Dr Martinick to discuss any apparent problems.
That the Federal Police who are not a representative of the Department of Health made the first contact with her.

That we are perturbed that the normal procedure of investigating an irregularity was not adhered to in this case and we request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should clarify this situation and amend the Health Insurance Act if necessary to ensure that the Medical Practitioners in future receive a fair and just hearing.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, Parliament House, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600. We, your petitioners, humbly showeth:

That permitting kangaroos to be commercially exploited when permissible cropping rates are unknown and the means of enforcing controls or protective laws are completely ineffective in this land, is allowing this unique animal to follow the path to rarity or extinction along which all wild animals have gone when subjected to exploitation in similar circumstances.
We Australians, have the right to see kangaroos in reasonable numbers on the landscape: We find the commercial slaughter of the kangaroo to be abhorrent and unjustified.
Commercialisation of wildlife should be stopped, particularly as exemplified by the kangaroo industry.
We your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will.
1. Ban the export of products made from kangaroos.
2. Take action to see that State Governments prohibit the commercial killing of kangaroos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its Wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Liquefied Petroleum Gas Subsidy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Bass respectfully showeth.
1. Although Australia is endowed with vast quantities of natural gas, Tasmanians are denied reasonably priced access to those resources. It should be shared equally between all Australians.
2. The Tasmanian householder using liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) pays $35.40 for an average household cylinder. In Melbourne, the same cylinder can be purchased for as little as $23.77.
3. A Tasmanian family on reticulated gas supply pays double the price paid by a Melbourne family on natural gas.
4. Tasmanian commercial and industrial users, paying high prices for their gas, are penalised.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government gas subsidy of $20.31 per tonne should be increased to Tasmania to compensate for Bass Strait freight charges. The subsidy should be raised so that Tasmanian users pay no more than the average of Austalian users.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Video Tapes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, electors of the Division of Calare show concern at the proposed classification guidelines of X rated video material which would do nothing to halt the sale and ready availability of same.
Your petitioners pray that a responsible attitude would lead you to outlaw production and supply in Australia and the import into the country of X-rated video tapes
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND REPATRIATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 June, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Carlton had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House expresses its concern at the plight of pensioners and beneficiaries whose incomes will be reduced as a consequence of the artificial reduction in the Consumer Price Index caused by the introduction of Medicare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill 1984 I note that the Bill contains amendments to seven various Acts, all of which cover an attempt to alleviate the circumstances of people in need. As indicated by the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), the amendments attempt in some cases to remedy anomalies and in other cases to improve benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that I find the amendment moved by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) rather ludicrous. The Hawke Government has done more to improve the lot of pensioners in one year than the Fraser Government achieved in seven years. During that terrible period of seven years the age pension dropped from nearly 25 per cent of average weekly earnings to less than 23 per cent of average weekly earnings. Now honourable members opposite are castigating the Hawke Labor Government because it is attempting to redistribute pension entitlements in aid of needy pensioners. I reject the amendment as a total misrepresentation of the Australian Labor Party's policies for the aged.

The problem with the provision of social security payments is that because the lives and the living circumstances of human beings are so complex it seems to be almost beyond the means of government to remedy all the defects of social security and repatriation legislation. Single parents are one of the most disadvantaged groups in our modern society, although I concede that Aboriginal groups and the under-18 unemployed are in an even more impossible position. Nevertheless, pensioners with dependent children, usually single parents, and usually women, are held fast in a poverty trap.

The recent example of a sole parent pensioner living in government subsidised housing with three children was presented in a paper entitled 'Trends in the Incomes of Australian Families' as a case study by a social scientist at the fifty-fourth Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science Congress in Canberra in May. That case study showed that with a supporting parent's benefit of $133.40, a family allowance of $21.75 and $20.12 under the secondary assistance scheme for the oldest child, less $26.67 rent, there was $148.60 left to feed, clothe and provide the other household necessities for four people-which was not exactly a princely sum.

However, if the sole parent took up a $100-per-week part-time job she increased her net income by only $38 per week. If the employer offered her a full-time job at $320 per week, she would have had to decline, because, with her pension lost, her secondary assistance grant reduced to $6.89, her rent increased to $80, a rise in child care cost to $26, travel costs of $10, a Medicare cost of $3.20, personal income tax of $56.80, and the coup de grace being the loss of her pensioner fringe benefits, she would have ended up with hardly any increase on her original single parent pension income.

Of course, some people might have the view that a sole parent would be irresponsible in not taking up a full-time job because at least that person would no longer be a social security beneficiary. I have no doubt that some honourable members on the benches opposite hold such a view. But what about the cost to her children? Such a view has no regard for the human cost that the sole parent's children suffer as a result of their mother not being available to listen to their cares and problems. If the sole parent could increase her income so that she could substantially improve her children's living standards and quality of life, it might be worth the sacrifice of being a part-time mother. But, for the paltry few dollars a week that she would gain from a full-time job, she had no alternative but to remain caught fast in the poverty trap. As the case study indicates, although there is some financial gain to a sole parent from taking up employment, the gain from earning $320 per week is approximately the same as it is from earning $100 per week. (Quorum formed). It is interesting that an honourable member opposite found it necessary to call a quorum. There are only five Opposition members in the chamber. That shows just how interested the Opposition is in social service beneficiaries.

There is little incentive for a sole parent-they are sometimes males but almost always females-in the circumstances indicated in the case study to become fully financially independent. However, there are methods of eliminating problems for social welfare recipients, such as sole parents. The Institute of Family Studies , in its May bulletin, indicated some alternative policy options in taxation and welfare transfer. The bulletin analyses the policy option of the impact of an increase in family allowance payments to allow the family to substitute the allowance for the major income tested payments for children. The replacement of income tested payments could be justified on the grounds of simplifying the existing provisions, increasing work incentives-as in the case of the previously quoted case study-improving the anti-poverty effectiveness and equity of income transfers, and providing a larger income for many non-pensioner mothers at home. A table is provided in the Institute's bulletin which I would have liked to incorporate in Hansard, but unfortunately the rules of the House preclude such incorporation.

I also wish I had the time to go into the details of the studies contained in the bulletin. They illustrate the great advantages of computer programs in examining the effects of government policies on social welfare and repatriation beneficiaries. They also indicate three options for providing income tax cuts without changing the basic income tax system. But they also highlight the plight of disadvantaged groups below the tax threshold level. It is essential that tax changes are planned in conjunction with policies which will assist such disadvantaged groups. As emphasised in the bulletin, there is a danger that the high cost of providing tax cuts to large numbers of taxpayers can squeeze out the revenue needed for other social needs, such as increases in pensions and housing rental assistance. It is to be hoped that, when the Government is considering income tax cuts in the Budget, it does not overlook those Australians whose incomes are below the tax threshold. In some senses the Bill before the House only tinkers with the system. However, the tinkering is to the advantage of pensioners, and I do not wish to appear to be carping.

I notice that the Bill will amend certain provisions of the Compensation ( Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971. I hope that these provisions will assist a constituent of mine, Mrs Patricia Owen, who suffered an injury whilst in the Army in 1962. The injury was aggravated by a car accident in 1964 whilst she was chauffering an Army officer. Mrs Owen was discharged on 26 November 1965 . She married the next day and she now has a teenage daughter. Correspondence between the Department of Defence and Mrs Owen has made it clear that the Department has accepted liability for the injury. Mrs Owen has had continuous treatment since 1965 and has suffered intense pain since that time, for which she has received medication. The medication has caused further physical impairment which restricts Mrs Owen's ability to live a normal life. She can walk only with difficulty and is completely unfit for work. Since 1965 Mrs Owen has received only $14,000 to $15,000 from the Army for loss of wages, and is at present attempting to live on the single parent pension and other benefits which , as has already been indicated, are totally inadequate.

I am concerned about the inordinate length of time which the assessment of the compensation claim is taking. Of course, I am not in a position to tell Mrs Owen whether the present amendments to the 1971 compensation Act will help her case. But I do wish that her claim could be dealt with more speedily. I quote from the most recent letter I have received from Mrs Owen:

Once again, I must ask for your assistance regarding my compensation claim with the Department of Defence. I apologise for bothering you once more as you have helped me so much with this matter last year. At present my claim is under consideration for total incapacity payments dating back to 1976 and I realise that with such claims there are rules and regulations to abide by, but on the 28th March I visited the Defence Department to find a way of easing the financial strain we are under. The Department gave me a letter, a copy of which I've enclosed, and told me although they were waiting upon a letter from Mr Shumack they would forward the file to Canberra. Last week I telephoned the Department to request a letter stating, if possible, a settlement figure on my claim. This letter was required by the Ministry of Housing to stop the monthly payments on my second mortgage until the claim is finalised. This could not be done because my file is still in Melbourne awaiting a final report and assessment before being sent to Canberra. I must mention that the gentlemen I spoke to was very nice and told me that any queries concerning my claim from the Ministry of Housing or the co-op be directed to him per telephone. It's just that so much of our future and survival depends on this claim and its settlement . I'm concerned that I'm told one thing only to find out another, and with my daughter going back into hospital within the next couple of weeks for the first of the cosmetic surgery to restore her face to its former beauty after the car accident last December.

I suppose I am being a worry wart over this claim but I'd like to think that after all the pain and suffering over the past and in the future will be eased with the knowledge that my daughter and I will be secure in our own home with a little set aside for that rainy day.
I remain
yours faithfully
P. Owen

My initial letter to the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes), requesting urgent assistance for Mrs Owen, was sent at the beginning of September 1983. It is now nine months later and Mrs Owen's financial circumstances have considerably deteriorated. I call on the Government to do something to help people like Mrs Owen who are in such great need. In supporting the present Bill, I call on the Government to look at its administrative procedures and to attempt to speed them up, particularly in urgent cases such as that of my constituent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take part in this debate on the Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill. As the speaker who has just resumed his seat, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), pointed out, this legislation can be described as tinkering with a very substantial problem. I suppose it is true to say that from time to time it is necessary to tinker and make marginal change, but it is essential for this country and for all Australians that at some time we take a long, hard, careful look at the total income security program that this Parliament has built up over many years and under many governments. Sadly, that system has been built up rather like Topsy, without any central theme running through it.

SPEECH.PARA: Very often in the building up of that system one aspect has been looked at and the effect on another has been ignored. This Parliament has mostly failed to identify the very close interrelationship between wages and incomes policy and the tax system that is used to tax the incomes of wage and salary earners and other income earners. It has also often failed to identify the interrelationship between those two matters-wages and the tax system-and the social security system. As a result we find within this country that only two out of five people have their economic security assured by the earnings they are making and receiving week by week. The remaining three out of five Australians are dependent. Some of those, about half, are dependent upon the public sector for most, if not all, of their income. The balance, just over half, are dependent upon other individuals for their income security. In many circumstances, those who are dependent upon other individuals have no income of their own.

The other day I had an opportunity to take part in another debate and I drew the attention of the House to the importance of the rising aspiration of more and more Australians to have some degree of personal economic independence. I note that in the legislation before the House today some changes are being made to the social security legislation, as the Minister for Science and Technology ( Mr Barry Jones) said in his second reading speech, to make it 'conform with the spirit of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984'. The Minister went on to say:
For example, references to 'dependent' female in the context of age, invalid, wives' and spouse carers' pensions, and unemployment, sickness and special benefits are to be replaced . . .

These references are to be replaced by what the Minister describes as 'the neutral non-discriminatory phrase ''de facto spouse'' '. I will have some words to say on whether this phrase is as non-discriminatory as the Minister implied.

For a moment I want to bring to the attention of the House the plight of the dependent female or dependent spouse. Whether we describe people as dependent or whether we choose not to so describe them because we think it discriminatory, the fact is that many spouses, the majority of whom are women, are dependent. They have no income of their own. They have no economic independence. It is true that such spouses are living in households with their husbands, in some cases with their wives, and that the other spouse is providing the income for the mini -economy-the household, the home and the family. Many of those who can be described as dependent spouses have no income of their own except, in some instances, the amounts they receive in respect of their dependent children in the form of family allowance.

This legislation is making some cosmetic changes but it really has not addressed the major problems, one of which is that the public sector, the Government, through the pension and social security system, will provide incomes only to some people, including the aged. Interestingly enough, when a married couple, one of whom has been totally dependent on the other throughout their working lives, attain the ages of 60 and 65 and become eligible for a pension, the social security system pays a pension to each. It does not ask whether during their working lives the household was a single income household and it does not pay a combined married rate pension to the person who was the breadwinner for the household. The social security system has recognised the importance of providing income to each of the spouses. To spouses of working age , in an economy not able to provide job opportunities for all those who would like some form of paid employment, whether it be full time or part time, the social security system says: 'It is quite all right, if you are living in a household with your husband, that you should be totally dependent on him and have no personal degree of economic independence from income that you receive in your own right'.

This cosmetic change to describe in certain circumstances as a de facto spouse a woman previously described as a dependent female totally ignores the reality of the position of many dependent females. The difficulty arises because of the separate assessments over the years in our tax system and our social security system. Many dependent females in the community and their husbands are gravely worried by newspaper speculation, no doubt fuelled by certain groups with influence within the Labor Party, about the possibility that the Government may achieve its tax cuts by abolishing the spouse rebate, an allowance made to a husband privately supporting a dependent spouse. The genesis of this allowance was in the claim that we had a tax system designed on the basis of capacity to pay. In assessing capacity to pay, we have recognised over the years that a taxpayer supporting another individual, an adult or a dependent child has a reduced taxable capacity.

I have often argued that we have not made adequate allowance for the support given by a taxpayer for a dependent spouse or a dependent child. But the reduced taxable capacity has been the genesis of the provision of that rebate. Of course it is true that the benefit of the reduction in tax flows to the taxpayer, mostly the husband but sometimes the wife. However, merely to suggest that the spouse rebate should be abolished will punish single income families, the great majority of whom today are in a single income situation for one of two major reasons. The first is that they have young children in their care and they choose to provide parent care to young children prior to their going to either primary or secondary school. The second major reason is that, even if the spouse in a single income family who has been caring for children has reached the stage when the children have grown up to an age at which the mother feels that she could seek employment, beause of the state of the economy, because of changes in economic circumstances, the jobs are just not available. So in those circumstances the dependent spouse is unable to get an income of her own and is extraordinarily grateful and assisted in the household budget by the fact that her husband, the sole breadwinner in the household, has a reduced tax burden. But that reduced tax burden is only part of the tax concession that is made available to the two-income household because the amount of the spouse rebate is not, as it should be, equal to the value of the tax free threshold.

For many years I have advocated that the tax system should be reformed so that people living in a household-mainly husbands and wives but it may be possible to extend it to other household economies-should be entitled to have their tax levied upon the basis of an income splitting or partnership arrangement between them so that it should make no difference whether one spouse, one adult in the household, earns all the income and shares it in the household economy in some way or another with those who are living in that household.

I still advocate that there should be a fairer system of tax so far as the single income household is concerned. But if we are to continue to provide that benefit through the form of a spouse rebate there are a number of things which I think should be done. In the first instance the amount of the rebate should, as I mentioned a moment ago, be increased to a value--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am reluctant to interrupt the honourable member but I cannot find any reference to the spouse rebate within the Bill to amend seven Acts, that we are debating at the moment. I will wait for the honourable member to return to the contents of the Bill.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I pointed out in my opening remarks that I believe one cannot look at social security legislation without also looking at the tax system because it would be possible to do for the spouse rebate what has been done for family allowances. The honourable member for La Trobe drew attention to family allowances. They were formerly given as a tax reduction, taking into account this capacity to pay principle, and, by a bold, imaginative and very positive move that recognised the changes that were occurring in society, the Fraser Government converted those tax rebates for children into an allowance which now comes through the social security legislation. So we have the two sides of the coin: Tax on the one hand and social security on the other. As I have already mentioned, the payment of those child allowances gave to many thousands of women a degree of economic independence.

SPEECH.PARA: Now I come to what I believe should be done with the spouse rebate. Firstly, it should be increased to a value equal to the value of the tax free zone to an individual taxpayer. Secondly, consideration should be given to the payment of a sum equal to the rebate as a cash allowance to the dependent spouse in order to give that person a degree of economic independence. That should be but a first step towards the recognition of the needs and interests of individual Australians for a fair and non-discriminatory arrangement in respect of the unemployment benefit.

The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) drew attention in his second reading speech to the fact that he was trying to make some changes-some cosmetic changes at that-to accord with the Sex Discrimination Act. The Sex Discrimination Act not only prohibits discrimination on the grounds of sex but also prohibits discrimination on the grounds of marital status. Today the people discriminated against by the social security system are married women. They are discriminated against as a consequence of the fact that they are not eligible to claim the unemployment benefit on the basis of their own income. They have to bring into account the income of their spouses. However, in this legislation we are changing the law to make it non-discriminatory by describing certain women not as dependent females but as de facto spouses.

I draw the attention of the House to the discriminatory administration of these provisions. It is very easy administratively to identify the fact that a woman or a man is a de jure spouse. It is easy for the Department of Social Security to ask: 'Are you married? Is there a piece of paper? Did you go through a formal , legal ceremony?'. The Department of Social Security then says: 'We will treat you as married. We will deny the unemployed spouse the unemployment benefit on the basis of a rigorous income test'. In the case of hundreds of thousands of households-increasing numbers of households-where there is a de facto relationship there is discrimination because of the difficulty of identifying when those relationships exist. I am not advocating for a moment that there should be prying into people's private affairs. What I am doing is drawing to the attention of the House the ease with which persons can be identified as married. The difficulty in identifying, in many circumstances, whether a de facto relationship arises is discriminating against those who are living as de jure married couples.

That discrimination means that many married women are deprived of the unemployment benefit when they would qualify for them under the work test. They are deprived because they are married and because it can be clearly shown that they are married. However, very often in the same street or in the same community there are many women known to be married women, living in a de facto situation, but nevertheless receiving unemployment benefits. They can be said to be breaking the law, but the fact is they are doing it in their hundreds and thousands. I am suggesting that we need to look at the social security system to try to develop a non-discriminatory method of delivering benefits to people who are properly entitled. We should not deprive women of the unemployment benefit merely on the basis that they are married. It may be that we should look at whether or not the income test that should be applied should be applied on the basis of the individual income of the spouse and that we should then make appropriate adjustments in the tax system to take account of the greater capacity of the husband to pay tax.

All I am urging is that we look at the total system to ensure that we achieve the social objectives that all Australians want achieved. They want a degree of personal economic independence. They also aspire to live as families, to live in households of husbands and wives and their dependent children. But they want a system that treats them fairly and with neutrality. It is interesting to note that some amendments in this legislation deal with the entitlement of spouses to the unemployment benefit. But, as was said earlier in this debate, that is only tinkering. It is making a very small change. It is not addressing the major problem or achieving the proper equity between married and unmarried couples. It is not providing women or men who are dependent on income earning husbands or wives with a degree of economic independence. Therefore, I urge that consideration be given to converting the spouse rebate into a cash allowance or to the payment of unemployment benefits on the basis of individual, not family, incomes.

I certainly welcome the opportunity to address myself to the Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill, which amends seven existing Acts, simply because the question of the aged in our society is of obvious concern to all, or should I say most, honourable members. This discussion ought to be undertaken in the most rational and sensible way possible because it is a challenge which faces this Parliament and which will face even the wider sector of the Australian community in the years to come. The figures themselves ought to compel a government into action. At present we know that some 12 per cent of the population is eligible for an age pension; that is not to say they will receive an age pension, but they are of an eligible age to receive a pension. In 20 years' time, at the turn of the century, that figure will increase to approximately 16 per cent. I understand that in the year 2020 the figure will be in the region of 21 per cent. Correspondingly, as the aged population increase escalates there will be a declining tax paying base; that is, there will be fewer people to pay for the services by way of taxation.

I was very interested in the manner in which Professor Gruen addressed himself to the matter of Australia's aging population in his recently released report which mostly dealt with the assets test. He makes a couple of interesting points which I am not convinced are absolutely correct. I call upon the Government to examine Professor Gruen's figures and his conclusions as they appear to be somewhat contrary to the expectation that Australia will have difficulty in paying for aged services as the years go by. For instance, Professor Gruen reaches the conclusion that, presuming there is a one per cent growth rate over the next 20-odd years, there will be no need to increase the tax base. He makes reference to the fact that as Australia's population ages there will be less need to provide social security, health and other related government services to the young. Similarly, he reaches the conclusion that the growth in the aged population will be only 0.71 per cent ahead of the general population growth.

I express some concern at those figures. I do not believe Professor Gruen had the terms of reference, the time or the facilities to address himself properly to these matters. But certainly it is very interesting and does appear to militate against our long-held fears that Australia will have real difficulty in paying for services in health, social welfare, housing and nursing for our aging population.

Professor Gruen's terms of reference were simply to decide the fairest type of assets test. His terms of reference did not allow him to say whether or not there ought to be an assets test, but simply what is the best form. The implication of drafting the terms of reference in that manner was that this Government wanted the most acceptable political assets test possible. For that reason, I do not believe the Gruen Assets Test Review Panel was able to examine properly, in a fair and unrestricted way, the provision of assets tests in the future. By that I mean that if the terms of reference had been properly drafted the Gruen Panel, although obviously not Professor Gruen himself, may have decided that an assets test simply would not work because of its unfairness to farmers, as the minority report pointed out, and the amount of money raised simply did not justify the dislocation caused to so many of the aged in our society. After all, on the Government's own figures, the assets test will raise only $45m in the first year and cost $30m to establish.

On my way back to my electorate on Friday evening I heard several radio broadcasts in which Professor Gruen challenged those figures and said that the test would raise only $45m in its first year and cost $50m to establish and administer. I heard those figures on several stations; I am not sure whether they are the correct figures. Perhaps the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) , who is at the table, will advise us later. Certainly to date there has been no Government rebuttal of the reported comments of Professor Gruen. If Professor Gruen's reported comments are correct, the Government will be $5m out of pocket in its first year.

Let us consider the harm it will cause a very significant proportion of our population. There are 170,000 family farms. The wives and the children will be affected. Very few, if any, of the numerous small business owners, all of whom undeniably are discriminated against by this test, will be able to receive the full pension, despite a lifetime of hard work, a lifetime of investment, and a lifetime of risk-taking-the sorts of virtues that have made this country great, the sort of individualism, entrepreneurship and initiative which we in the Opposition are proud of and seek to encourage. Yet this Government, with its obsession with the public sector, its dismissal of our traditional values and traditional work ethic, has thrown all that out the window. In short, the Government is saying to these people: 'Drop dead'. It has washed its hands of these people. It does not want to know them. As a result of that shortsighted, narrow, ideological, blinkered view, the economy will suffer. It is only through a healthy, vigorous private sector that we ensure the growth and profit that create long term employment.

There are three matters in relation to the Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill that concern me. The first is clause 41, which amends a section in the Social Security Act that provides for the payment of the unemployment benefit to be postponed for a minimum of six to 12 weeks in certain circumstances. Those circumstances would be fairly well known to honourable members but they can be summarised by saying that if a person's unemployment is due to his misconduct as a worker the Department of Social Security can postpone a payment of unemployment benefit. Further, if in the opinion of the Director- General a person is a seasonal or intermittent worker, or the income of that person during a period of temporary employment is sufficient for the maintenance of himself and the persons who are ordinarily maintained by him, the Director- General can decline to pay the unemployment benefit for a minimum of six weeks to 12 weeks. This clause will give the Director-General far greater flexibility and far greater discretionary power. These changes will mean that payment of unemployment benefit can be postponed only up to 12 weeks at the discretion of the Director-General or his delegate. The simple fact is that this will become the norm. It waters down this proposition to a point when it will create what the Opposition believes is an unacceptable weakness. I believe that the changes will ensure that this provision in the Social Security Act will be used rarely. I think there are some dangerous implications in that. It appears to me to be an absolute abdication of responsibility by the Government.

I have further concerns about clause 74 of the amendment Bill before the House. Clause 74 gives effect to the Government's respite care program, which was announced by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) on 11 April this year. The program introduces a respite care subsidy for eligible persons in eligible hostels. The problem here is that the subsidy will be paid to approved organisations. The definition of 'approved organisations' excludes hostels operated by organisations for profit. In other words, as I read the clause, a resident can obtain a respite care subsidy only if the hostel is run by a non- profit organisation. Therefore, any hostels or nursing homes run by persons for private profit appear to be excluded. I trust that the Minister will address himself to this matter in summing up. Again we see that the private sector is being disregarded.

I have visited hostels and nursing homes which are in private hands. The stringent requirements on them by the Department of Health, the Department of Social Security and the State departments are extraordinarily high, and so they ought to be. If a private body or a private person is to run a hostel for profit it is incumbent upon the Government to ensure that the standard of care, the standard of nursing, the standard of accommodation, equates with that of government-run hostels. I do not argue that; in fact I strongly support it. Given that private organisations running hostels for profit satisfy those criteria-again I stress that they are very strict criteria-I do not believe that they ought to be excluded from receiving the respite care subsidy.

Before leaving clause 74, which deals with the respite care subsidy, I wish to raise one small problem which a number of hostels have raised with me already in regard to this program, and that is the problem of empty beds. Some hostels have complained that they are ensuring that there are empty beds in the event that somebody wishes to take advantage of the respite care subsidy, but they believe that the beds are remaining empty for far too long while they have a waiting list. I realise that this is undoubtedly the crux of the problem when trying to provide emergency short term accommodation. I acknowledge that problem, but I wish to draw the Government's attention to the snags, if I can use that colloquialism, that have already appeared. I ask the Government to take note of that and always to be aware of it. I certainly do not have a solution off the top of my head, except to say that the situation obviously requires careful monitoring.

In drawing to a conclusion I again add the Opposition's support to the amendment moved by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), which gives attention to the fact that the Medicare levy has artificially reduced the consumer price index. Since so many pensions are automatically indexed to the CPI pensioners will lose out. I understand that the honourable member for Mackellar has presented to the House figures which show how much pensioners will be out of pocket as a result of the Government's fiddling, if I can call it that , with the CPI. The CPI as it stands is not a true economic indicator of the cost of living. I believe that this House ought to pass the amendment, which states very plainly:

. . . the House expresses its concern at the plight of pensioners and beneficiaries whose incomes will be reduced as a consequence of the . . . reduction in the Consumer Price Index caused by the introduction of Medicare.

This is an opportunity for those members of the Government who have spoken previously, who have hailed themselves as the saviours and protectors of the aged and the pensioners, to put their money where their mouths are, to show that they are not just mouthing pious platitudes which at the end of the day do not amount to anything. If they are really concerned about the plight of pensioners, if they are really concerned to provide in a proper, fair and equitable way for the aged people of our society, they will support that amendment, as will every member of the Opposition.

The policy of this Government at election time included an incentive to keep people at home. Many people have always lived in a particular area. They know their neighbours and perhaps they have relatives in the area and for a whole range of reasons they would like to stay there. An old friend of mine is living at home but he has now reached the stage where he cannot bend over and cannot mow his lawns. All he needs is someone in the home for up to five hours a day; then he could stay there. When we look at the high cost of accommodating people in institutions and hospitals, surely it is cheaper to keep him at home. Yet this old gentleman has to make a decision. Will he try to stay at home and cope with a limited amount of home help or will he go into an institution for which he is not yet intellectually, and probably physically, completely suited?

There are many other people who have retired in certain areas. I am thinking of areas such as the Mornington Peninsula in Victoria, the south coast of New South Wales in my electorate, the north coast of New South Wales and a whole lot of the coastal areas in Queensland and other States where people have gone to enjoy their retirement. The Government is to be congratulated on making this small move of encouraging people to live at home. This provision for respite care provides help not only for those people who would like to stay in their homes, in the area in which they have chosen to live , but also for the carers of the people. I believe that there is a lot more to be done, but the Government is to be congratulated on facing the need of people to stay where they are if at all possible, not only because it is socially better for them but also because it often ends up being cheaper. As we face the challenges of new technology and the challenges of early retirement, more and more people will be retired and this will become a bigger problem. The Bill provides for two rates of subsidy-$10 a week for each respite care bed occupied by an eligible person or persons for at least one day but for not more than 14 days in any four-week period ending on a prescribed date; and $50 a week for each respite care bed occupied by an eligible person or persons for more than 14 days in any four-week period ending on a prescribed date. This Government is instituting an element of choice. The respite care proposals are a most important element in that provision of choice. As the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) said in his second reading speech, a survey by the Australian Bureau of Statistics showed that there are three times as many frail aged people over 65 with a disability living in their own homes rather than in institutions. This Government wants to ensure that those people have the chance to stay in their homes rather than be institutionalised. I have never met anyone who was actually keen to go into a nursing home if he had a choice. Honourable members will recall that I was the chairman of a committee that spent a fair amount of time looking into programs for the aged. We brought down a report for this Parliament, many items of which have been picked up by the present Government and put into its aged care program .

The respite bed provision is one of the most important provisions of the present Government's aged care program. It helps aged people and it takes a particular load off their families. One of the main problems with the institutional services that have been provided in Australia in the past and a feature of the nursing home benefits system that was controlled by my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) was that the previous nursing home system subsidised bed occupancy. It paid one for a body in a bed. It did not subsidise nursing home services per se. Therefore, that was an incentive for nursing home proprietors to have beds occupied in order to achieve maximum profitability. In fact, under the previous Liberal Government anyone who wanted to go home for the weekend to see his family or go on a holiday with his family had to get a certificate from the Minister, which was a terribly cumbersome bureaucratic approach. The present Government will now fund respite beds which will allow those people who are presently frail and in their own homes to go into a nursing home for a few weeks or for a month from time to time during the year. That will give them the chance to have some rest, or medication if they need it, and it will also give their families or the relation who is looking after them the chance to have some time to themselves.

This program over the next three years will provide 1,350 beds at a cost of $3. 5m; not a great deal of money, but a very important move to assist a range of aged people. In the few moments left to me I wish to canvass one other matter which comes within the ambit of the responsibilities of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs ( Senator Gietzelt) and which I think he may like to take on board and consider in the next few months. I suggest that he have a look at those people who are presently eligible to insure their houses with the Defence Service Homes Corporation home insurance scheme. At present honourable members will be aware that all veterans who served overseas in a declared war zone and those who are serving members of the Australian defence forces are eligible to take up a defence service home loan. Once one takes up that loan one is eligible to enter into an insurance scheme somewhat like the scheme being run by the Commonwealth Banking Corporation for people who borrow money from that bank to purchase a home. Such people are allowed access to a scheme which enables them to insure their houses at quite competitive rates, rates which are much more competitive than those in the private insurance market.

At present the only people who are eligible to take up that insurance are those who currently have or have had a loan with the Defence Service Homes Corporation . So it applies only to people who were able to borrow money from the Corporation in the first instance. At present about 200,000 people are insured through that scheme. However, a large number of people are eligible to take up loans, but because of the shortage of funds they have not been able to take them up. It is estimated that there are about 350,000 people in that category. That is nearly double the number who have loans.

I think that it might be in the Minister's interests to have a look at extending this insurance scheme to all those eligible veterans and Service personnel. It would cost the Government nothing to do it, but would provide a considerable benefit to veterans and to defence personnel, who would then be able to insure their homes at a much cheaper rate.

We always hear the insurance industry saying to the Government that it is very gung ho on free enterprise and very keen for competition. If a Government corporation can compete with private industry, I think that is good. I hope that the Minister will give consideration to extending this scheme to all eligible veterans so that they can participate in it. I thank the House for its time, and I congratulate the Government for its initiative in particular in bringing in the respite care provisions, which will be applauded by all those people who are doing their best to keep themselves in their own homes at present and who want to see out their years there. —Is it not a fundamental point that as the cost of living goes up so too should pensions? That was a Fraser Government initiative. We legislated to make it automatic. What happens under the Medicare racket? My colleague, the honourable member for Mackellar, calls it the 'Medicare fiddle'. I say it is the Medicare racket. If the Government were composed of a bunch of solicitors they would all be in gaol. Under the Medicare racket the CPI is tampered with because the Medicare element comes out. What will that mean to the pensioners of Australia? It will mean that as from November of this year the pension increase which would have been granted will be chopped by $2.15 a week in the case of single recipients and $3.58 a week in the case of married couples. SPEECH.PARA: When we look at this change in terms of the total increase, the plain fact is that it is a cut of between 20 per cent and 40 per cent of the increase, depending on the level of inflation. As the honourable member for Mackellar said last night in his outstanding contribution on behalf of the pensioners of Australia, if we take it further to May 1985 and no adjustment is made by this wicked Government, the effect will be compounded and we will have an additional loss of $2.22 a week for single pensioners and $3.70 a week for married couples. So it goes on. As the honourable member pointed out, and I want every pensioner in Australia to realise this: Effectively, the pensioners of Australia will be making a contribution of $213m to subsidise the Medicare racket.

If that is not bad enough, let us look at the assets test. I am conscious that the Bills in respect of that are not before us and my remarks therefore will be abbreviated. What sort of heartless, cruel and vicious government is it which says without any mandate-nothing was said about this in Mr Hawke's policy speech -that it will impose an assets test which, on its own admission, will cost the revenues of Australia $30m in the first year, which will persecute and terrorise not 25,000 to 50,000 but, I say, between 50,000 and 100,000 Australian pensioners, and which will require the hiring of an additional 1,500 public servants or, if you like, inspectors, or, as somebody said the other day, storm troopers, to check on the assets of the pensioners of Australia?

That checking will not be done just in this country, because this cruel, wicked and vicious Government has not said whether it will include assets owned by pensioners overseas. Where is the justice in this situation? Three young Italian people ask their elderly parents to come out from Italy to spend their last years in Australia. The elderly parents come, leaving two of their children back home in Italy. The elderly couple depend on the pension. They have a small, modest home in Australia, which they have bought. They have in Italy a little home in their names which the two children living in Italy will be able to inherit. Is that little home in Italy in or out of the assets test? Does the Hawke assets test mean that we will send inspectors to Italy and Greece to check out the value of property left back home? Does it mean that if an Italian lady of senior years leaves some jewellery in Italy to be worn by her daughters and daughters-in-law somebody will get a trip to Italy to check it out? This is not to be laughed at. Let me remind the House that 500,000 migrants-it is my honour to be the shadow Minister responsible for immigration-fled to Australia from totalitarian regimes which expropriated property and assets both before and after death. They are petrified, terrified, by what is now happening in Australia under the Hawke socialist Government.

On a lighter note, Mr Deputy Speaker, like you, I get around the electorate as soon as Parliament adjourns. Last weekend at, I suppose, seven or eight functions I would have been seen by and would have seen hundreds, if not thousands, of my constituents. An old age pensioner, a bit of a card, a man with a good sense of humour like yourself, Mr Deputy Speaker, said to me: 'I want you to put up a trophy for a competition'. I said: 'Fair enough, Bill. What is the competition?' He said: 'We want to run in every senior citizens club in Australia a competition'-for which, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will put up a $10 trophy-'Pick the pensioner who is going to vote Labor at the next Federal election'. Do not let it be said that my friend the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard), for whom I have a deep affection and who is trying to interject, is a party to this cruel, wicked and vicious attack on the elderly. Why does the Hawke Government not pick on people its own age? What a lowly government it is! Here comes the socialist Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) into the chamber. It says: ' We will not let you keep his motor car valued at $11,000. You can walk'. In 16 years in politics, as a State and Federal parliamentarian, I have never seen a government so callous in its disregard of people whose votes it courted. It went out for the pensioner vote. This Minister carries a very heavy moral responsibility because he was no doubt the architect of the vicious attack on the pensioners of Australia which the Prime Minister and his colleagues have perpetrated since they came to office. The plain fact is that for ideological self-satisfaction he presses on with an assets means test which he knows will be a cost to the revenues of this country-$30m in the short term. I challenge that figure. On the basis of information supplied to me by a senior public servant, I put it to the Minister that the figure will be closer to $50m. I repeat: I reject his claim that it will affect only 25,000 to 50,000 pensioners. When he failed to lift the tax threshold he claimed that that would affect only a small number of pensioners. The plain fact is that 280,000 pensioners are paying tax this year under the Hawke socialist Government who did not pay tax under the Fraser Government.
