SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill 1984. We have just listened to another fiery speech from the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) which was, as usual, full of wind, full of rhetoric but lacking in substance. To coin a phrase, it accentuated the negative and eliminated the positive because it did not pay attention to the contents of this Bill. There was no attempt to look at the Bill as a whole. No attempt was made to look at what the Bill is attempting to do. The Bill reflects the concern of this Government in improving the welfare provisions of those in need. This Government inherited a social welfare system which was failing to deliver adequately the level of income and other supports required by the disadvantaged, the handicapped and the aged. This point has been well made by the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), and I will not traverse the comments that he made in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I will refer briefly to the comments made by the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) who, unfortunately, is not in the chamber at this time. I feel he adequately explained to the House-and I pay tribute to him-the problems of the aged. I support the tenor of a number of his comments relating to their concerns. I also concur with his comments about the role of the parliamentarian being that of a highly paid social worker. I suppose that as a social worker by profession it is for me a natural progression to be in this House and to be involved in this debate. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), in his opening remarks, paid some considerable attention to the effect of the cost of living on pensions and this is so. Certainly the cost of living has had its effect on pensions. Since this Government was last in office the single rate of pension has fallen relative to community incomes and it is now about 23.25 per cent of average weekly earnings. As a government we are committed to maintaining a rate of pension of at least 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. In contrast the disposable income of taxpayers has generally increased in real terms but these increases have been less for families with children than for families without children.

Before discussing some of the issues raised in this Bill I would like to refer briefly to the issue of the welfare state as a random redistributive device. It is sometimes suggested by the Opposition-I do not include the honourable member for Mackellar-that income redistribution resulting from the welfare state goes at times to people who do not deserve to have those benefits. This, I feel, is an unfair representation of the Australian social welfare benefit system. Podder and Kakwani's 1975 pioneering study, based on the Macquarie survey of 1966-68, established that cash benefits and transfer payments had a much greater equalising impact on income distribution than the income tax system at that time . Kakwani, in a more recent study-1983-based on the 1975-76 household expenditure survey, estimates that cash benefits reduce income inequality by some 15 per cent and that benefits are far more redistributive than taxes. It is also estimated that an additional 10 per cent of the population would be below the updated Henderson poverty line if there were no transfer payments. It is against that background that I wish to address my remarks concerning this Bill.

The Government, within a few days of coming into office, showed where its concern was by raising the unemployment benefit for some 312,000 single adult unemployed. This was stage 1 of lifting the unemployment benefit to parity with the standard pension and was indicative of a new and fresh approach by this Government which contrasts with the niggardly and negative approach of the previous Government. Since then a succession of measures has been aimed at redressing the inequalities caused by the substantial shift of wealth and tax benefits to the highest income earners. Not least of these measures to have redressed the balance has been that of Medicare.

I now turn to the amendment to the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954. This will provide for special short term accommodation for frail aged and disabled people in subsidised hostels. The honourable member for Grayndler has already praised the scheme. I feel that the scheme must be praised in this House by members of the Government. The respite care program would increase the options of frail aged and disabled people who wish to live in the community rather than to go into hospitals and other institutions permanently. Under the program it is expected that some 1,350 respite beds will become available over the next three years, half of which-that is 675 beds-will become available in 1983-84.

In our election policy we promised to introduce incentives for the provision of suitable short time respite accommodation for people being cared for in the community so that their carers may have a break from caring for elderly, frail or disabled people. Research has shown that many sick or frail aged people prefer to live in the community, either with relatives or alone. This is their choice which we as a caring community should accept. It minimises their dependency and provides a better lifestyle for them as they remain in familiar surroundings and with people they know. The 1981 Australian Bureau of Statistics survey of handicapped persons in Australia showed that more than three times as many severe to moderately handicapped people aged 65 years or older lived at home as lived in institutions. Many more would make that choice and be able to improve their quality of life if community services were more available. However , a heavy onus is still placed on carers under the present system, as it will be in any future system. It seems the heaviest burden will be placed on relatives and friends.

The alternatives to these proposals, to these supports in the community, are permanent and premature admission to institutional facilities or acute hospitalisation, often to costly private hospitals. In order to qualify for the subsidy hostels must maintain beds for the purpose of providing respite care services. Hostels with up to 50 beds would be expected to keep one bed for respite care and hostels with over 50 beds would need to maintain two respite care beds. Hostels will be subsidised $10 a week for respite care provided for 14 days or less in a four-week period and $50 a week if care is provided for 15 days or more in the period.

A number of other amendments in the Bill are worthy of note by the House. The first one is the supplementary rent allowance which will be paid to a sickness beneficiary without dependants who is hospitalised. This will assist such people to meet rent payments while in hospital and to secure continued tenancy. In the past I have known of persons coming out of hospital, finding that they are homeless and having to seek alternative accommodation at a time when they are not in a position to walk around the community in order to find such accommodation.

Another amendment will remove the anomaly under the benefits income test where in the past the total benefit received by a married couple with private income- both of whom are entitled to benefit in their own right-can be significantly less than when only one spouse received the combined rate of benefit. The amendment will ensure consistent treatment for pensioners. In general, the amendments contained in the Bill are indicative of the attitude of this Government towards assisting those most in need. As I said at the beginning of my speech, this Bill reflects the concern of this Government to improve the welfare provisions of those in need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill I think the first thing that should be said is that it does contain some very sensible amendments which will go some way to easing problems for members of the community. However, the Bill is fiddling around the margins to a large extent on the question of income support, particularly retirement income support. The question has to be asked yet again why the Government does not address this question as a whole. That is a matter to which I will come back in a moment. But it is ad hockery.

SPEECH.PARA: What is happening, particularly with regard to the assets test announcement in the last few days, concerns old people. Old people do not know what is coming next. They are battening down the hatches and reaching out for advice and support. As an indication of that I mention that in one day before lunch time I had 40 phone calls to my electoral office from older people asking what was going on and what would happen next.

I commend some of the provisions of this Bill. For example, I commend that clause concerning the supplementary rent allowance for those who are hospitalised with no dependants. This problem will be addressed. Such people have been penalised in the past. In the past they have had to maintain the accommodation in which they were living and to which they will return. Those premises still have to be secured. I think this provision is an equitable one.

In regard to lump sum payments, people who received their lump sum superannuation in instalments have been penalised in the past. I think it is also a sensible amendment to put them on the same footing as people who get their lump sum superannuation in one go. It is a great pity that the question of lump sum superannuation, as a whole, is not addressed in such a sensible way. The tax on lump sum superannuation-the tax introduced by this Government-is discouraging people from looking after themselves. Why should there not be some choice in this area for people who want to enter into schemes which give them a lump sum payment or which give them a pension? The Government will insist on dragging everyone into the one mould. This is the philosophy that dictates the Government's approach to the lump sum superannuation question. There are members of the community, particularly servicemen, policemen and teachers, who move constantly during the course of their career. They need that lump sum to re- establish themselves in normal civilian life when they have to retire. Without that lump sum they will be grossly disadvantaged.

The provision to change the existing legislation which denies people who leave a job, for one reason or another but without sufficient reason, benefits for six to 12 weeks is, I think, a mixed blessing. I understand why it is being brought in. No doubt many people in the past have been penalised because they could not get the unemployment benefit for a long period. My concern simply is this: Will it not encourage the irresponsible to leave jobs or to manufacture reasons for being sacked from jobs, maybe very frivolous and flimsy reasons, just because they are bored? Will they leave, knowing that they can get the unemployment benefit immediately if they tell a story sufficiently convincing to the Director -General of Social Security? There will be a lot of such people. There will be people who will manufacture those reasons. The Director-General of Social Security obviously, even with the greatest delegation, will not be able to address himself to all those people frivolously claiming the benefit immediately . I think that we will have to face up to that concern.

The remote area allowance provision is sensible in that it will remove discrimination against people who live in remote areas. I particularly applaud the supplementary rent allowance, which will be given to those who live in caravans, of whom there are many, or houseboats. Some live there through choice and some because literally they have nowhere else to go. In the past they have been disadvantaged because they have not received a supplementary rent allowance . I am very pleased to see the introduction of a supplementary rent allowance because I know that so many constituents in my own electorate have suffered as a result of the lack of such an allowance in the past. Respite care, which the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) and other speakers have mentioned, is to be commended. Keeping people in their homes as long as possible is something that we as a community should be encouraging.

This Bill raises some other questions. One such question is the distinction between benefits given to married and unmarried women. The Government has made a lot of noise recently about and introduced many Bills to support the elimination of discrimination against women on the grounds of sex or marital status. We have a real problem, a social problem, whereby a man and a woman can live together and both be entitled to and receive unemployment benefit, for example, because there are not enough inspectors to go round checking-I suppose we do not really want it-to see exactly what are the circumstances under which they live. Yet when the income test is applied to a man and woman who are married where the husband only is working, the woman is discriminated against as she is not entitled to receive unemployment benefit.

I am not seriously suggesting that all married women should get unemployment benefit, but there is an anomoly. One of the reasons more and more people are choosing not to get married is that they see themselves as being financially disadvantaged. It is not an easy problem to overcome. It is happening increasingly all over this country. Unfortunately, the effect is to downgrade-in many younger people's minds, anyway-the institution of marriage, which I think is a sad reflection on the sort of approach we are taking to marriage in this country. In some ways it is an attack on the family.

This legislation, as good as it may be, is really only tinkering with the question of income and support, particularly retirement income. It is very difficult to understand why the Government rushes in, for example, with an assets test when the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare is examining the whole question of retirement income and is due to report in August on the very question, the broad question, to which the Government should be addressing itself. Why would the Government rush in with yet another assets test, having abandoned that which it introduced in September last year because it was unjust and unworkable, and put in place another scheme, the broad outline of which appears to be equally unjust and unworkable?

If the sorts of questions that I am getting in my electoral office and that other members on this side of the House-and I have no doubt members of the Government as well-are getting from older people in the community are any indication of community feeling, why has the Government abandoned one unworkable test and put in another? The only reason can be that the arrogance of the Government has now become paramount. It believes that it can walk on water. It abandons one scheme, introduces another unworkable scheme and discriminates against the aged. The Government has the wind in its sails and does not give a damn. We are seeing an attitude that became predominant during the Whitlam years , and look at what happened to that Government! The same thing will happen to this Government if it continues to disregard the feelings of a significant and growing proportion of the Australian community. There are one and a half million age pensioners. That percentage of the community will continue to grow. There is widespread concern and confusion out there because of the arrogance of this Government.

In simple terms, it seems to me that there are two ways to approach the question of retirement incomes. One way is to institute an income and assets test, which is proposed to be set in place. The other way is to look at a contributory scheme for people during their working lives so that everyone at a certain age and under certain conditions is entitled to some benefit without the hassle of inspectors and declarations and all that goes with the current income and assets test. It is not an easy question, but I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the Government is going down the wrong path. Can we as a community afford to keep rummaging through the lives of elderly people, peering at and assessing their income and assets, at a time when they should be entitled to some peace, dignity and certainty that the income on which they have planned will be there? They should not have to pick up the paper and find that yet another test is being instituted with all the concern and confusion that that brings.

On this side of the House we are often accused of being silvertailed Liberals who do not understand the problems of the aged. It is an accusation that I reject out of hand. People on this side of the House, as do people on the other side, know only too well the problems of the aged. But the difference in our approach is this: We are also concerned about the creation of wealth so that it can be redistributed to those in need, whereas the philosophy on the Government side is simply to redistribute the existing wealth. That is a dead end, because by doing that the people who create the wealth will eventually give up as it is not worth the candle. If the Government continues with its philosophy, it will be left to redistribute nothing because there will be nothing to redistribute.

Let me turn to the matter of repatriation benefits. The Government is addressing this problem and we will be debating it later this week. I am very pleased that the Government is addressing the problem and I congratulate it for doing so. In broad terms, those who are in receipt of repatriation benefits or who are claiming repatriation benefits have to wait an extraordinary amount of time to receive them. I believe that the system which the Government is introducing will reduce that time. It is a major problem at the moment. At the end of March there were something like 1,205 outstanding new claims compared to March last year when there were 684, that is, double. This year appeals to the Repatriation Commission, assessment cases before the Repatriation Tribunal-one could go on and on-are almost double what they were last year.

The waiting times are even worse. Let me take the most extreme example. The average waiting time for someone appealing to the Tribunal is 600 days. The reality is that many veterans, because of their age, die before their claims and appeals are heard. So it is a major problem. It has been growing. I am glad to see in the Bill that we are discussing that those repatriation beneficiaries are being brought into line in respect of the social security benefits which the Bill also introduces. For goodness sake, let us address this problem. If what the Government is proposing does not work, let us make sure that the legislation is amended to make it work. We cannot go on and on denying benefits to veterans because of the extraordinary delays being experienced in that Department.

In conclusion, I congratulate the Government for some of the measures which are being introduced in this Bill which will help a lot of people. I urge the Government to take a broader look at the overall and broad question of income support, particularly retirement income support, to wait for the Committee to report and not to rush in with something as disastrous as the assets test is proving to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I pointed out yesterday, the operation of the present income test provides a 12-week period for adjustment in relation to this matter. In our original assets test there were similar provisions in relation to assets. Yesterday I made the unequivocal declaration that we would not have a period of less than 12 weeks, that is, less than the present period for the incomes test, when this occurs. I did say that we would look at representations in relation to this matter before the Bill comes before the House. As the Bill is not even before the House I have, over the last week, done my best on the information we have at this stage to provide a broad outline of the assets plan. I said about this very point yesterday that the details would be provided in the context of the Bill being brought into the House.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me say something else about the whole form of the attack of the Opposition on these proposals. The Liberal Party of Australia is the Party which, for seven years up to last March, believed in needs based welfare. For almost seven years that Party denied unemployment beneficiaries under 18 years of age any rise whatsoever in their benefit. When they were asked why, what did they say? They said that benefits and pensions should go only to those in need. Again, for almost seven years the previous Government refused to index the benefits paid to adult single unemployed beneficiaries. What did it say when we asked them why? It said benefits and pensions should go only to those in need. That Party devised the most intrusive test into the sexual relations of de facto couples, single parent beneficiaries and unemployment beneficiaries that this country has ever seen. What did it say when asked why? It said that benefits and pensions should be paid only to those in need.

We know where that Party stands now. Of course it believes in a needs based welfare system, but only for the poor and the underprivileged. The poor and the underprivileged should be subjected to any tests that that Party believes desirable, but if it is suggested that asset rich pensioners, particularly asset rich farmer pensioners, should be tested, that is something that cannot be done. There is a term for those kinds of double standards. What we have on that side of the House at the moment is an Opposition which is simply a masquerade for organised hypocrisy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Finance confirm that, since entering office, the Labor Government has increased spending substantially in a number of areas and that there is talk of more new programs for 1984-85 in addition to a promised tax cut? Can the Minister say how the Government has controlled growth in outlays to date and how it will continue to do so and avoid growing deficits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the House that, since this Government came to office, it has set about the most thorough-going redirection of public expenditure which has ever been undertaken by a government. What we were confronted with at the time of the change of government was a very dramatic expansion in the growth of outlays. Indeed, in 1982-83 we had seen expenditures grow by 18.5 per cent during a desperate spending spree on the part of the Fraser Government, just before its death throes. So we were confronted not only with a prospective deficit of $9.6 billion in 1983-84 but also with the prospect of that growing even further in 1984-85 unless we took the action we decided to take in the 1983 -84 Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: We were able to cut out and redirect $1.2 billion worth of program expenditure to reflect more accurately the priorities of this Government and redirect funds into the areas of housing assistance, community employment programs, health assistance and the like. At the same time we were able also to eliminate $0.6 billion worth of tax expenditures which had been provided mainly to the friends of the Liberal Party of Australia. As a result of this approach we were able to reduce substantially and bring under control the growth in outlays in 1983-84. As a result of this clear-sighted approach to public expenditure we are ensuring that the taxpayers will get value for money. We recognise and insist upon a creative and productive role for the public sector, but we want to ensure that there is an absence of waste and that public expenditures go into areas of greatest need and achieve important social and economic priorities.

As we approach this Budget and as we approach the question of making our expenditure decisions for this year we will be taking the same kind of approach to expenditure priorities. In the 1984-85 Budget we will be aiming at not only a reduction in the size of the deficit and the provision of worthwhile tax cuts but also a reduction in real growth in outlays for the first time in four years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security to the fact that over one-third of the members of this Hawke Ministry failed to correctly fill in their pecuniary interest forms and were not penalised in any way whatsoever. Will the Minister assure the elderly of this country that no pensioner who fails to correctly fill in his or her assets test form will be put in gaol, as is the current intention of the Government?

—Unlike the Leader of the Opposition, I have complete confidence in the honesty of pensioners in filling in these forms. Under the present system in relation to income tests, where people make errors which are not deliberate, these are treated with complete tolerance by the Department of Social Security. We will adopt exactly the same procedures in relation to these matters. It is only where there are efforts to deliberately disguise information or knowingly to provide information that is known to be false that action will be taken. On the whole we are quite confident that the great bulk of pensioners will be able to provide the information and, having confidence in their honesty, we believe that in nearly all cases that information will be perfectly acceptable.

—Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs inform the House of the action he took during his recent visit to Moscow to register the deep concern of the people of Australia at the inhuman denial of human rights by the Soviet authorities to the Nobel Prize winner and peace campaigner, Dr Andrei Sakharov, and his wife, Dr Yelena Bonner?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raised this matter in a quite unambiguous way with Mr Gromyko and in a much more public situation in Moscow a little over a week ago on the occasion of my recent visit. Before going to the Soviet Union I had made it clear through communication to the Soviet authorities, using our representative in Moscow, that I would be raising this matter. It was suggested that it was not desirable that the matter be raised and that there would be some objection to it. I made it clear that, as a matter of moral obligation, the people of Australia, including all members of this Parliament, would expect that I should raise the matter and that, frankly, I would find myself morally deficient if I were not to raise it. Accordingly, we proceeded with the intention to raise the matter.

ANSWER.PARA: I raised the matter first in a quite public way in an address which I delivered at a luncheon which Mr Gromyko hosted for me. The address was rather extensively reported in Pravda. If I can observe, it was a much more extensive cover of an address by me than I have been able to achieve in Australia. However, I must also say that there was a delicacy of expression in the reporting that one does not usually discover here. For instance, it said, in truncated fashion:

Further, Mr Hayden touched on the problem of human rights in the usual way of the Western countries. He set out the well-known Western position on negotiations on nuclear arms, claiming that the United States and Western governments wanted the achievement of an agreement on curbing the arms race and detente.

I should add, in fairness to Australian journalistic standards, that although the coverage was somewhat more extensive than that which I usually enjoy here, little bits were left out here and there. The following is one of them. More pertinently to the matter the honourable member for Hawker has raised, I said:
It may be difficult to put old disputes to rest, and new disputes will certainly arise. Competition between us will certainly go on.
Then this was omitted in the report:
But this must not be taken to mean that, when we raise with you the issues in dispute between us, we are challenging the very foundation of the Soviet state or Government.

For example, I will raise with you during my visit certain matters relating to human rights. My reason for doing so is not to use human rights as an instrument of propaganda against the Soviet Union, nor to interfere in the purely internal affairs of your country. That would be wrong. Rather, I will do so as a reflection of our belief that human rights know no boundaries.

For an Australian Foreign Minister to raise these matters is a reflection not of antagonism towards you, but of the deeply felt concerns and values of my countrymen and women. It is for that reason that I have raised such matters in a number of other countries whatever their governmental or social system. I have made it plain that, if a Foreign Minister visiting my country were to raise human rights matters on the basis of genuinely held conviction, I would not reject that as an interference in our internal affairs. I would not like it-I do not invite it-but I support the right of anyone to pursue, with vigour, the cause of human rights.

That particular quote ends there, although the deletion goes on for another page and a bit. When I met Mr Gromyko I put to him directly the concern of this country, this Parliament and this Government. It was made clear to me on the part of Mr Gromyko that it was not a matter he wished to have pursued in discussion, that the Soviet attitude is that Soviet law applies to Soviet citizens, that it is the sovereign right of the Soviet Union to determine according to its laws how Soviet citizens will be dealt with and that it was an unwarranted and unacceptable intrusion from other countries for them to seek to raise matters relating to Soviet citizens.

I equally firmly pointed out to him that in the matter of human rights there are obligations on all member countries of the United Nations incumbent from the provisions of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights but that, more than that , according to the standards that we accept, the philosophy that guides us, there are things such as natural law and natural rights which rise above the codification of any laws by any sovereign country, and should a sovereign country codify laws which breach those principles we believe the natural law and natural rights rise above what has been done by government.

That matter was persisted with quite firmly. I would have wished that the resolution of this House of Representatives had then been carried with unanimous support from all corners of the House. I would have conveyed that to Mr Gromyko. I understand that the Senate will be moving to discuss a matter similar to that which was discussed in this chamber on the matter of Andrei Sakharov and his wife, Madam Bonner. I have no doubt that the outcome there will be similar. I understand that the Prime Minister's attitude is that the unanimous attitude of both Houses of this Parliament should then be conveyed to the Soviet representative in this country to be passed on to the Government of the Soviet Union. I conclude by saying that there is no doubt as to Australia's attitude- not just my attitude but the attitude of all members of this Parliament and the Australian community-on this matter and related human rights matters so far as the Soviet Union is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. In view of his advocacy in this place as to the equity of the new proposals relating to the assets test, I wonder whether he would advise the House, in the light of the comments yesterday by the Minister for Primary Industry about the impact of the assets test on farmers, how the ability to deed property to family five years before pension eligibility and still obtain a pension will help those farmers who are seeking a pension now, how it will aid widows who suddenly find themselves with major assets which cannot be quickly disposed of and how he expects farmers and their wives who take this so-called option to live for five years after they have given away their only income- producing asset.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I pointed out earlier this week in relation to a similar type of question, there are very clear hardship provisions provided under the legislation. Those are designed to deal with some of the very specific problems that have just been raised by the right honourable member for New England. Let me point out that in relation to some of these hardship provisions-they particularly relate in this case to farmers-where a person is unable or cannot reasonably be expected to raise money on a farm or where selling the farm would cause hardship, consideration will be given to exempting all or part of the value of the farm from the assets test.

ANSWER.PARA: Where a farm may be in a pensioner's name but worked by one or more of the farmer's children for little or no wages for many years on the understanding that the farm would be theirs on the farmer's death, again, all or part of the farm could be exempted from the assets test. Where a farmer wants to remain on the land but generates only a small income from the farm, then the hardship provisions may also be applicable. So, first, there is a series of hardship provisions which will be embedded in the Act. Secondly, as has been pointed out by my colleague the Minister for Primary Industry, there are a number of strategies which farmers can adopt, and with which many of them are very familiar. I am talking about legitimate strategies. As has been pointed out, that may not be completely comprehensible to the right honourable member for New England. There are clearly a number of legitimate strategies which are open to farmers.

Finally, there is the provision that a farmer may take out a loan from the Department of Social Security against the property, which would be dealt with on the settlement of the estate. Despite all the noise on the other side, that is simply an elective option. It is not something which farmers are compelled to do . It is one of a wide number of options that farmers can take under this legislation. As the Prime Minister pointed out the other day, it is much better to have this option, for which a farmer can voluntarily elect, than not to have it in the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment as the Minister responsible for consumer affairs. Is the Minister aware of the serious potential danger to children associated with plastic novelties that are now available in shops? What action is the Minister able to take to protect consumers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the potential inhalation and ingestion hazard presented by some plastic toys that are now available and can be purchased in Australia. I do not want to emulate my colleague the Minister for Science and Technology too much, but I have in front of me a small plastic crocodile, which is bought in an egg.
—Did Barry Jones give it to you?

—If the honourable member will wait and hear what I have to say, he will find that this is a very serious question involving a dangerous matter. These crocodiles, or items of a similar nature, when placed in water, can swell to a size of several cubic inches. If a child swallows one of those, there is a fair chance that it will choke to death on it or get it into the stomach, which will necessitate possibly a major operation to remove it.

ANSWER.PARA: This is not a matter of humour; it is a matter of tremendous importance. The product is extremely dangerous. It has been banned in Great Britain, Sweden, Thailand and a number of other countries. I have declared this toy to be unsafe under the provisions of section 62(d) of the Trade Practices Act. The ban will take effect when the notice is gazetted, which I hope will be later today or tomorrow. My Department is pursuing measures to ensure that suppliers immediately withdraw these items from sale and to check that any items sold to children do not pose a safety hazard. The measures include a constant checking by the Trade Practices Commission and investigation by all State authorities and consumer agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that I have withdrawn from the Notice Paper question No. 1353 standing in my name. I now address my question to the Treasurer. In the light of his answer to me yesterday, when he said that Robert J.L. Hawke committed no breach of the Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations as a result of his possession of $1,000 in United States currency, subsequently stolen from his suite at the Boulevard Hotel in Sydney, is it a fact that section 5(1) of the Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations forbids unlicensed persons buying, borrowing, selling, lending or otherwise exchanging or dealing with foreign currency in Australia? As Reserve Bank policy in 1982 required proof of immediate overseas travel for issue of foreign currency, what legal process was available for Robert J.L. Hawke to acquire the $1,000 in United States currency, so mysteriously stolen, and for which the Prime Minister does not want a prosecution?

—I have nothing to add to what I said yesterday. I made it abundantly clear yesterday that the regulations do not impinge at all upon the holding of foreign exchange. They relate to the buying and selling of foreign exchange. The current Prime Minister, then as a private person, registered the theft with the police because he was holding that foreign exchange. As I said yesterday, as the honourable member well knows, there has been no breach of the regulations in holding that exchange. If the honourable member has taken the question off the Notice Paper he will have saved me and my Department a lot of time in answering questions which have no basis whatsoever.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer him to the national accounts figures released yesterday and, in particular, to the 2.3 per cent figure recorded for the non-farm gross domestic product implicit price deflator. Does the Treasurer consider this to be a true reflection of the course of inflation during the March quarter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been some confusion with the national accounts. I noticed on radio today and in the Press that a number from the accounts has been quoted, quite correctly-the gross non-farm product deflator, at 2.3 per cent-implying that there is an acceleration in inflation over the quarter. Whilst that figure is correct, it is erroneous in the sense that the Statistician says at item 9 of his explanatory notes, referring to the deflators:

ANSWER.PARA: Movements in the levels of individual implicit price deflators can be greatly affected by changes in the physical composition of the aggregates and their components.

That has happened on this occasion. Because the deflators are not fixed weight indexes but can produce quite substantial distortions as a result of changes in composition-changes in composition, I believe, in this case, coming from changes in stock levels-the compositional effect is roughly one per cent. Looking at the accounts yesterday in respect of gross fixed capital expenditure deflators for dwellings, non-dwelling construction and equipment, we find that the figures are 1.6, 1.7, minus 1.2 and 0.4, and for domestic final demand, 1.3. That tallies with the fact that a correction which would be made, appropriately, for these compositional changes, would reduce the gross domestic expenditure deflator, or the gross domestic product deflator, or the non-farm deflator, at 2.3, 2.4, and 2.3, by roughly one per cent.

That tallies when one looks at the consumer price index before the Medicare adjustment at 1.2, which lines up with the 1.3 on the domestic final demand deflator, and on the national accounts for the year to March the gross non-farm product deflator is 7.7, which compares also with the CPI at 7.6. While there are some details to comprehend, I indicate that the gross aggregate deflators, registering 2.3 and 2.4, are, I am advised, in compositional terms overstated by about one per cent. In fact, we are really looking at about 1.3 or 1.4.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Foreign Minister. I refer to the very eloquent declaration of concern about human rights which the Minister has made and which I think would have found an echo on both sides of the House. In light of that, I ask the Minister whether he raised with Mr Gromyko the continuing Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. If so, what was the response?

—No, I did not raise it directly with him. But I publicly declared our condemnation of it in front of him at the luncheon to which I referred. So there is no doubt about our condemnation of the invasion of Afghanistan. We did not soft-pedal on it. I raised many other matters with him. But if the honourable member is keen that the matter should be raised with the Soviet authorities, I will ensure that our representative in Moscow reminds them of the fact that our opposition to it was clearly and unambiguously declared at the luncheon. But there is no doubt that it was registered.

—Will the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism inform the House of the success or otherwise of the recently launched domestic tourism campaign featuring Paul Hogan? As I represent an important tourist region, I would like him to say what impact, if any, this campaign will have on the Australian economy and what growth, if any, will be generated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to inform the House, and particularly the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, who quite properly pointed out that he represents an electorate with a very strong tourist component, that the recently launched domestic tourism campaign has been an overwhelming success. It pleases me to note that this Government is the first Commonwealth Government ever to involve itself in the promotion of tourism within Australia. It says something about the lack of understanding of the previous Government of tourism generally and particularly of the very important factor that tourism within Australia- which, I might add, is by far our biggest industry, employing 400,000 people-is 95 per cent domestically oriented. It is absolutely beyond me why previous governments have not developed tourism within Australia, but it is no surprise to most people who traced the course of the previous Government's lack of any sort of economic knowledge.

ANSWER.PARA: The campaign which was launched in April was jointly funded. The Federal Government contributed about $1.5m. The States made a contribution of $0.5m. An amount of $1.5m was garnered from industry, which is another innovation because the previous Government could never get industry to involve itself in this sort of scheme. We have implemented a tripartite system. Across the political lines the States have co-operated effectively with the Commonwealth Government in promoting this very important campaign. The results are quite stunning. Honourable members may have noticed this morning in the Australian Financial Review a survey of airline movements within Australia in the first three months of this year. Passenger traffic is up by 5 per cent, which says something about what we are trying to do. I inform the House that if we can improve domestic tourism by just 5 per cent, we will immediately create another $600m worth of gross domestic product and 20,000 new jobs.

I am sure that all members of this House will be pleased to learn that on the best estimates available 20,000 new jobs have been created this year in the tourism industry. The campaigns which this Government has started have generated the investment of $6,000m in new resorts, hotels and motels around Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not so.

—I know that it will not interest the honourable member for O' Connor. He would not care if the record of unemployment fostered by the previous Government continued. We have created almost 200,000 new jobs in Australia in 12 months; 20,000 of them happen to be in tourism. I can assure you, Mr Speaker, and the House that this campaign, the first domestic tourism campaign undertaken by a Commonwealth government, has been an outstanding success.
—What about the depreciation allowance?

—That comment is so innocuous that I will not answer it. Let me say in conclusion that it is nice to find one area of interest within the economy which is likely to grow and which has support across the political lines , although probably this has not seeped through to the Opposition. At the conclusion of the meeting of the Tourist Ministers Council the other day in Adelaide the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Burke, who has responsibility for tourism in Western Australia, without prompting moved a motion congratulating the Commonwealth Government on its initiatives and leadership in tourism.

—The Opposition has not yet heard the punch line. The motion was supported and seconded by the Minister for Tourism in Tasmania, the Minister for Tourism in Queensland and Paul Everingham, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory.

—Will the Minister for Defence assure the House that productive land will not be acquired for an infantry training centre, artillery range and manoeuvre areas for the Services in New South Wales? If so, will he withdraw the contract now let to Dames and Moore until other more suitable land is available for consideration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find the question quite interesting, especially as the right honourable gentleman told people outside the Parliament today that he had rejected the proposals for the artillery range. I think the House is entitled to ask the right honourable member to provide evidence that he had done so, because there is no knowledge of his rejection of it in the Department of Defence or the Australian Army.
—I will be very happy to respond. Mr Speaker--
—Order! Is the Leader of the National Party of Australia raising a point of order?
—No, he was asking me to respond. I was giving him the answer he sought.
—It could be in his diary.
—Order!

—I also suggest to the right honourable gentleman that, as he was a Minister in the Government which initiated this process, he would know that the then Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, the honourable member for Bass , and the then Minister for Defence, Mr Killen, approached the New South Wales Government and informed it in the strongest possible terms of the necessity for this project. I also point out to the House that the right honourable member for New England recently, in a radio broadcast, advised that he had not published the details of the proposals which he had received in November 1982, and had sat on them for five months--
—Because I rejected them.

—He did not reject them and he cannot show any evidence that he did. Now that he is in opposition he has a different view of his activities from that which he had in government. He is frightened of his constituents, from whom, as the Minister, he deliberately withheld information. The information on the designated sites which were agreed by a New South Wales and Commonwealth working party was provided to the then Minister for Defence and now Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Sinclair, in November 1982.
—And they were rejected.
—The Leader of the National Party has the documents. Let him table the documents which show that he rejected the proposed sites.
—Order! I call the honourable member for O'Connor on a point of order .
—Mr Speaker, I was going to raise the point of order that there are hundreds of people deeply concerned--

—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. There seems to be a habit of raising frivolous points of order which have no relationship to the Standing Orders. Following the next incident of that nature, I will name the honourable member concerned without warning. I call the Minister for Defence.

—The House should be fully aware that this project was processed to the extent of identifying the areas under study by the former Government, and none of the areas was withdrawn by the former Government. It should also be pointed out that, despite the right honourable gentleman's protestations now, his answer on a radio program a few weeks ago in Tamworth was that the areas under consideration were not announced because an election was pending and it might concern the people that their homes were in the investigation area.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts of this matter are these: There is an urgent and pressing need, identified by the former Government when in office and when displaying some responsibility on defence matters, for areas to be available for the training of personnel in the handling of artillery which can no longer be fired on the range at Holsworthy because of its capability and the urbanisation of the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you have to take productive farm land?
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—You do not want to make yourself cheap by getting into this sort--
—You could do it somewhere else.
—I warn the Leader of the Opposition.

—A clear statement on this matter has been in existence for 12 months . The right honourable member for New England did not even know that I had made the statement a year after I had made it, until it became a political football. Suddenly he is running for cover on decisions that he and his Government fully supported.
—We did not.
—I warn the Leader of the National Party.

—He may have convinced himself that he had rejected it and forgotten to tell anyone else, but he certainly did not seek or have the agreement of the Government of which he was a member. The fact is that there are three areas under consideration. A report will be made by consultants hired to do the specific job of identifying those areas which meet the requirements of the Australian Army for training and for the relocation of the School of Artillery. I should indicate that there is both opposition and agreement to the Army training facilities proposal. I have seen at least 10 groups in the last two weeks supporting and opposing it. This Government has no wish to continue the uncertainty any longer than necessary, and the matter could have been five months further advanced had the right honourable member for New England not sat on the proposal for that period. We cannot finalise an area for study until such time as the consultants' report on the suitabilities within the criteria already laid down is received.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not the Government's intention, as I have said on several occasions, to acquire prime agricultural or highly productive land. Certainly densely populated areas would be unsuitable if for no other reason than that we could not afford to acquire them because just compensation will and must be paid. If the right honourable gentleman were not so concerned about short term political gain, he might sometimes take into consideration the national requirements and the requirements of Australian defence and the responsibilities which one might expect from a person who purports to be the alternative Prime Minister of Australia, albeit a very thin alternative. The Government will process this matter as quickly as possible and will not be totally irresponsible by playing cheap politics like the former Minister, who was quite prepared to process the matter provided nobody knew about it before the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I preface the question, which concerns the strike by Commonwealth car drivers, by expressing my appreciation and, I am sure, that of all honourable members for the Minister's action in having in place at very short notice replacement transport arrangements.
—I hope that the honourable member is coming to his question. That seemed like a pretty ample prologue.

—Will the Minister inform the House of the circumstances which led to the present strike involving Commonwealth car drivers, the likely duration and extent of that strike and action taken to bring the strike to an early end?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The strike by passenger drivers is confined to the Australian Capital Territory, I am pleased to say, and involves not only the drivers but also the supervisors. With regard to the preface to the honourable member's question, that credit is due not to me but to the transport officers, John May and Frank Stewart, who achieved a very quick and capable solution to the problem facing us all. The strike arises from a demand made on my Department by a group of drivers representing the other members of the union that a written undertaking be given that all appointments of driving supervisors come from the passenger driving staff. That is something with which I would personally have sympathy as long as the applicants were of sufficient merit. There are five vacancies for transport supervisors at the moment and negotiations have been going on to fill those positions. The recommendation about those positions made by a committee comprising representatives from the Public Service Board and my Department is that four of those positions should be filled from within the passenger driver complement and one from outside. I think that is a fairly decent and generous proportion of drivers achieving an increase in status.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been assured that the recruitment and selection processes were in accordance with the due process prescribed under the Public Service Act, which provides for selection on the basis of merit. The strike action breaches an undertaking reached with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, including the Transport Workers Union of course, over the implementation of a 38-hour week. The demand at the root of this strike-that is, for a written undertaking that all positions of this kind be filled from within the passenger drivers staff- would constitute a breach of the Public Service Act, and we are not about to accept that. At this stage the TWU has indicated that the drivers will return to duty on the first shift tomorrow morning. Meanwhile, my Department is consulting with the Public Service Board on the matter and the best contingency arrangements possible at this stage have been put into place to ensure that members, senators, office holders and staff will be catered for in the best possible manner.

Any one of the areas would be suitable for an infantry or artillery school.
—Order! The right honourable gentleman knows that he should not go beyond correcting where he has been misrepresented.

—I am doing that, Mr Speaker. I think it is necessary that it is understood that I did not sit on these proposals because of a precipitate rush to an election in the manner of this present Government. The Minister, in his answer, suggested that I had sat on these proposals because of an imminent election and therefore did not process them. The reason why they were not processed was that they were not accepted.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister also alleged that I made a comment on a radio station, apparently in my electorate, that the reason they had not been processed was that it was before an election and apparently I did not want to arouse the ire of my local constituents. My comments relating to these areas have always been that with respect to the artillery range and manoeuvre area I did not believe productive agricultural land should be used. I believed consultations should take place between the Federal Government and New South Wales to determine further areas of investigation.
