TALK.START.PARA: —Now that the initial development and implementation of CEP has been successfully achieved, it is appropriate to review the possibilities for further development of the program. It is for this reason that over recent months I have consulted extensively with State Ministers, local government and community groups on the changes that may be necessary to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the program in 1984-85.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of specific guidelines which have caused concern amongst various sections of the community involved in CEP. I refer in particular to the sponsor contribution and labour intensity requirements of the program. As I announced in the House yesterday, the Government has decided to make some changes in this area for 1984-85.

While the Government is still strongly committed to the principle of sponsor contributions, it is also keenly aware of the difficulties experienced by some areas of local government and the community in meeting the current requirement for a minimum sponsor contribution of 30 per cent of total project costs. Accordingly, I announced that the following changes will be made: A reduction in the minimum sponsor contribution for local government and community groups from 30 per cent to 20 per cent of total project costs; a removal of the right of exemption from this level of contribution for local government sponsors; and a more consistent and realistic approach to the use of non-cash contributions by local government and community groups, up to a limit of 10 per cent of total project costs.

Under these new arrangements, sponsors in the local government and community sectors will also be obliged to ensure that 65 per cent of the Commonwealth grant is devoted to the direct wage costs of the target group. This requirement will ensure that the employment creating impact of the program will be maintained, while at the same time offering more flexibility for sponsors in terms of the labour intensity of individual projects. These new arrangements, which will apply from 1 July, will provide greater consistency and equity across Australia and will allow a more realistic basis for the continued participation in the program by the local government and community sectors.

Another key issue for the future will be to ensure that the program is targeted effectively to the groups in most need of assistance. This is particularly important in view of the magnitude of long term unemployment and the fact that applications are far exceeding the level of Federal funding available. The objective should be to ensure that the most disadvantaged groups participate in the program at a level greater than their proportion of unemployment. Although women are participating substantially in the program, we obviously have to intensify our efforts to achieve the overall objective of equal participation.

There are, of course, broader issues of relevance in considering the future development of CEP, such as the role of training and other support services. In particular, I am keen to consider program developments which cater for a more structured integration of relevant training activity and which ensure that employment opportunities are closely linked to the emerging structure of the broader labour market.

Mr Deputy Speaker, now that the program is being effectively implemented, it would be tragic if it were to be disrupted by the industrial action of Commonwealth Employment Service staff members as a result of a national ban proposed by the Australian Clerical Officers Association on all new CEP vacancies after 15 June. Such an action would represent a devastating blow to the employment aspirations of the most disadvantaged people in the labour market . I find it difficult to believe that CES staff, whose dedication and effort I have admired in my period as Minister, could undertake such a callous and unconscionable action. This is particularly so when the Government has responded in a reasonable manner to the staffing needs of the CES to this point, and remains concerned to ensure adequate staff levels in 1984-85.

To this end, the Government has acted to increase staffing levels for the CES by almost 5 per cent during 1983-84, which means that CES staffing levels have risen by 27 per cent over the two years to June 1984. As part of this increase- and contrary to the assertions of the ACOA-the Government specifically provided for 256 staff to implement the CEP program through CES offices. Furthermore, the Government has twice invited the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and its staff associations, to participate in discussions on staffing levels throughout the Public Service in the context of the 1984 Budget preparations, during which the Government will be implementing a process of human resource budgeting in conjunction with financial budgeting. Such discussions would, of course, provide the ACOA with the opportunity of being involved in consideration of CES staffing levels for 1984-85, as well as staffing levels for all other areas of the Public Service.

This is the first time any Australian government has made such an important opportunity available to the staff associations. It would be a tragedy for the unemployed and a setback to the achievement of a more rational approach to public service staffing issues if this offer is rejected in favour of callous industrial action.

In concluding, I reiterate the important role the CEP has to play in the Government's policy strategy for reducing unemployment. I also commend the positive role that honourable members on both sides of the House have played in ensuring the success of the program. Members have been given the opportunity to be involved in the development, assessment and announcement of projects in their electorates, and I am pleased that many honourable members have participated in these activities. Through this program the Government has clearly demonstrated its commitment to directly tackling the serious problem of long term unemployment. I trust that we will continue to receive broad community support and involvement, as well as the bipartisan support of this House, as the program goes into the next financial year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), in his closing remarks, referred to the general bipartisan approach to this problem. I refer to his earlier analysis of the economy, with which I agree, which referred to the difficulty which long term unemployed and other disadvantaged labour market groups have in getting any employment at all and the fact that the longer they are out of work the greater their loss of work skill and self-confidence and the more reluctant employers are to take them on. We acknowledge the other remarks of that character. It is one reason why we have not been critical of some aspects of the administration of the community employment program.

SPEECH.PARA: But, without departing from that bipartisan analysis and concern about the state of the labour market and the problems of the long term unemployed and some of the other disadvantaged people, it is fair to point out that the community employment program is suffering from serious maladministration. I hasten to add that I do not believe it is maladministration on the part of the Minister's Department. Nonetheless, that Department must accept a great deal of the responsibility for the oversight of the program. I shall return to that matter in a moment. From what the Minister has said today, it is very clear that this program is failing to meet its objectives of providing much needed short term employment and work experience for the unemployed, especially those disadvantaged people to whom we have referred.

The Government introduced the CEP through legislation brought into this House more than a year ago, in fact on 19 May last year. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) officially launched the program on 1 August. That was a huge lapse, presumably for administrative reasons, but I think the occasion is well remembered. The publicity occasioned by the launching by the Prime Minister was that the project was funded by the previous Government's wage pause employment program. Today, more than 10 months later, we hear the Minister say that the CEP is now fully operational. The tenor of his remarks was that this was a matter for congratulations of the Government. He said that the Government was getting the program off the ground. That is not an occasion for congratulations by the Opposition or the community, because the program was, as a wage pause employment program, under way with essentially the same guidelines. It seems to us that if it is off the ground it is in a state of stall and is in danger of serious crash landing.

I remind the House that following an agreement of 7 December by the then Federal Government and the State Premiers to introduce the wages pause it was agreed that there would be an employment program of this character funded from the money saved by the pause, saved from salary increases which had been allocated but which would not be actually granted. In the short time between the making of that agreement on 7 December 1982 and the election on 5 March 1983 a great deal of progress had been made in getting in place essentially what the Minister now says is safely launched. In fact, the wage pause program led to some 4,000 projects and of the order of 22,000 jobs which lasted a little less than six months. An interim report was produced by the Bureau of Labour Market Research confirming that the wage pause program substantially achieved its objectives. I remind the House that those objectives were essentially those of the community employment program. So it is very disappointing to hear the Minister saying that this program is now off the ground. He said:
. . . the actual operational results of the program to date have also been impressive.

They are far from impressive, and that is very sad indeed for those who had hoped to benefit from the program. The fact is that the Minister will have to provide a good deal more information about the progress of the CEP if the House is to believe his statement. Such information as the Opposition has been able to assemble indicates that, far from being a success, the CEP is in the throes of major breakdown. Nothing the Minister has said today does anything to allay those fears. Indeed, the lack of information tends to corroborate them. The House will note that virtually everything the Minister said was in terms of applications lodged for CEP grants and approvals given. The Minister states that he is confident that the CEP will achieve its aim of providing 40,000 jobs lasting an average of six months in the financial year 1983-84, but we are now within one month of the end of that financial year and the results are far from encouraging. The Minister has stated today that 16,360 applications for CEP funding have been received. I do not doubt that figure, but what evidence is that of the program's success in creating employment? I submit that it is none at all. The evidence is that the community recognises the value of a program of this nature, properly administered. That is the number of applications; that is not successful projects for a program that is a year old.

The Minister further says that 6,570 CEP projects have been approved. Again, I do not dispute that figure. Projects are easily approved. I understand that the State CEP committees are under considerable pressure to approve them. But of those 6,570 projects approved, the Minister admits that, after 11 months, only 2 ,300 have actually commenced. With one month of the financial year to go, only 35 per cent, just over a third, of the Government's target number of CEP projects have actually begun. Forty thousand people are to be assisted by the CEP projects already approved, but with one month to go fewer than half that number of people have actually benefited through receiving employment and work experience. So it is one thing to talk about applications; it is quite another thing to talk of approvals and commencements. The Minister says that this rate of commencement will accelerate over the remainder of the financial year; but of course, that remainder is only a matter of weeks. There is very little of the financial year left, so one would have to say that the community is entitled to be disappointed with the first year of operation of this scheme.
I should like to ask about a number of matters of administration. I say at the outset that my personal regard and liking for the Minister, both as a person and as a Minister, is very well known.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are only human.

—Yes, the Minister is only human. I understand the complexities of his administration only too well, especially when it involves State bureaucracies; so I hasten to make it quite clear that I am concerned to identify-as I am sure the Minister is, but he did not wish me to do so-the problems of administration which are obviously revealed by this statement and the figures that have been tabled. Therefore, I ask the Minister whether it is true that, under the CEP, New South Wales has been allocated $85m, has committed $150m, but in fact has actually managed to spend only $11m. Is it also true that the situation is almost as bad in other States? As I am informed, in Western Australia, for example, there has been an allocation of $23m in CEP funds, a commitment of $40m, but a spending of only $6m. The Minister will need to explain that to the public before long. We really need to have a proper examination of why it is that this program, which so many people wish to see successful, is not being administered appropriately at a State level.

SPEECH.PARA: How does the Minister explain those figures? It seems to me that they represent a breakdown, caused, no doubt, by a lack of co-ordination and supervision by the Commonwealth and certainly some very strange administration at State level. Is it, for example, true that the Western Australian CEP Consultative Committee has not even met for two months, as I am informed-since 9 April-because of a serious rift between the State and Federal governments? That is my information. The House has the right to know the answers to these questions, and so do the taxpayers. According to the Minister, they will have invested $400m of their funds in this program. Also, of course, the 670,000 unemployed, many of whom had hoped to benefit from this program, have a right to expect better than they are getting. It appears very clear that the State bodies charged with approving CEP projects are being pressured to do so without sufficient guidelines or supervision from the Federal Government. In particular, they are approving projects without first assuring themselves that there are sufficient target unemployed in the places where the projects are being approved. So jobs are available in certain places, but target unemployed under this program are not necessarily where those jobs are, and the projects are not being approved in places where the targeted unemployed would be able to benefit from them.

The Minister has rightly pointed out that the CEP is not designed to provide ongoing funding for community services or other activities or to enable sponsors to develop services or facilities using the best labour available. He goes on to say:

While the provision of worthwhile community services and facilities is an important element of the program, the primary objective is to provide employment opportunities for those most disadvantaged in the labour market.

Of course, we fully endorse that, and that was the purpose of our funding under the wage pause program. But this objective is not being met, and while projects continue to be approved without a prior profile of the local employment or unemployment market, including the targeted unemployed, the program will continue to fail in its objective. Nothing that the Minister has said today has allayed the fears of those who believe that that is one of its major shortcomings.

The fact is, as well, that the CEP is being widely abused. I do not doubt that there are some successful programs, but from all over Australia one hears stories of how local councils and some of the community organisations are using the CEP as a soft touch for funding. It is widely known that, if a local organisation approaches a local council or State government body for funding for a particular project, the council or the government body replies: 'Put in an application under the CEP'. I am not suggesting that the matter has reached the proportions of rip-offs under the regional employment development scheme, but I am saying that, support the objectives of the program though we do, we shall have to ask increasingly, and increasingly aggressively too, some questions about the administration of it. Organisations are getting around the requirement of 30 per cent funding by project sponsors. The Minister has announced a further reduction of that, but in the past they have successfully applied for an exemption or, in some cases, have contrived to fulfil the requirement by providing volunteer labour to the so-called value of that 30 per cent. In either case, they are avoiding committing any finance and they are able to spend the taxpayers' funds with minimal accountability. I repeat that we praise the objectives, but we really believe that the CEP is not proving effective at present. The Minister and the Government must pinpoint the reasons why and must account, on their next presentation to this House in the Budget session, much more fully for the maladministration at State level and, therefore, Commonwealth supervision of it, which is quite evident from what I have said today.

Apart from requiring a much greater level of efficiency and supervision from the Government, the public will also want to be reassured that its funds are being prudently spent for the purpose for which they have been allocated. On 4 May I asked the Minister some pertinent questions raised in the second progress report on the prices and incomes policy. He has not answered them, so I shall refer briefly to them again. That report records that over 20,000 jobs were created under the previous Government's wage pause program, at a cost of $223m. It further estimates that under the CEP program 23,000 jobs will be created by projects approved as of February this year, at a cost of $379m. Given that the average duration of jobs under both programs is six months, I believe that the Minister ought to explain why the jobs created under the current CEP program are costing 43 per cent more-almost half as much again-than the jobs of a comparable character and for a comparable duration created by the previous Government's wage pause program. Moreover, the Minister ought to justify to the House-he has not done so-the expenditure of an additional $156m to create an extra 2,600 jobs . That figure works out at about $60,000 for each additional six-months job.

I wish to refer to a couple of other matters of detail. One matter is that complaints have been received that, in South Australia at least, before people are enabled to participate in CEP projects they must join the relevant union. I trust that the Commonwealth will inform State governments administering this program that that is not a feature of the guidelines and that that practice-if the allegations are correct, as I am informed-ought to cease.

Another matter to be raised is in respect of the Minister's statement that the jobs on local roads component excludes the 50 per cent female employment objective because of the nature of the project involved. I ask why that is so, particularly in light of yesterday's discussion on the Green Paper on affirmative action for women, and particularly in light of the Minister's statement today when he referred to the growth in employment of women under the repairs and maintenance program. As he rightly observed, this compares very favourably with the traditional practices of the building and construction industry. I put it to the Minister that the nature of modern road construction is such-it is so capital intensive, with a great deal of equipment-that what was presumed to be male work in that respect is now no longer so, and that the objective of 50 per cent female employment ought to apply.

Another matter of importance relates to the Commonwealth area. I think the Minister was silent on this matter. But in the area of Commonwealth employment, if one looks at a breakdown of the grants allocated last year, the Government allocated $19.2m on general projects and about $20m on housing and construction. Eighty-one per cent of all jobs were funnelled into electorates held by the Australian Labor Party and only 19 per cent went to electorates held by the Opposition. I think the Minister owes an explanation to the House in that regard as well. The difference is even more marked in the general projects area. Eighty -seven per cent of general projects went to ALP-held electorates and only 13 per cent to seats held by the Opposition. I believe that an examination of these figures suggests that the Government has engaged in pork barrelling of a very blatant kind. The Minister will have an opportunity to clarify those figures. They are identified from figures which the Minister tabled on a previous occasion.

I raise one further matter relating to the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association's threat to ban community employment programs. I endorse fully the Minister's condemnation of the ACOA. I also join him in his remarks about the dedication of the Commonwealth Employment Service staff. I believe that the CES must consider very carefully what the Minister has said. The Minister is correct in recording that CES staffing levels have risen by 27 per cent over the two years to June this year and, on that basis, CES officers do have an obligation to consider the plight of the unemployed. What their threatened ban-and, indeed, what their existing ban on some of the other employment programs-amounts to is a strike against the unemployed.

The Minister has expressed his views very strongly and I trust that when he, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the ACOA and other staff associations examine the staffing requirements for the next financial year-and when, as is inevitable, they disagree-the Government will then take a very firm stand with those unions and that those unions will see the importance of standing by the plight of the unemployed.

The Minister, in his opening remarks, spent quite a bit of time on the so- called 'legacy' which he inherited from the previous Government in respect of the economy. Let me say three important things: We all know that this Government has been astonishingly lucky in the way in which the drought ended; the way in which it got the benefit of the wage pause program; and the way in which there has been some recovery in the world economy. But we also know that in its management of the economy, in its implementation of the accord with the ACTU, it is squandering the benefits that were provided to it. It is doing so in a way which will lead to no growth in employment such as can absorb the growth in the work force, let alone offer prospects for those who are intended to benefit from the program under discussion today. Participants at the National Economic Summit Conference held in this chamber talked about jobs, jobs, jobs. Yet the policies which this Government is pursuing are designed to inhibit sustained economic growth. Today the Minister said:

. . . the Government recognises that the task of making substantial inroads into the level of unemployment will not be easy. The modest improvements in the unemployment situation can only be consolidated and substantially improved upon in the context of sustained economic growth over a number of years.

But the policies being pursued are against the features that guarantee that investment will be made by the private sector to bring about that sustained economic growth. The growth in jobs matches the growth in the work force only for the time being and the prospects are that the growth in costs of employing people will outstrip the capacity of industry to invest and therefore there will even be a stalling in the growth of jobs which will fall behind the inevitable growth in the work force. But the important thing is that the people who stand to benefit under this program not only are not benefiting to the extent that they should, but also will not benefit while the Government pursues policies which seek to give a great deal to those who have secure jobs at the expense of those who do not have jobs.

This Government must work out its priorities with the trade union movement for the benefit of the employed. It cannot, every time it makes a major statement, say that it inherited a mess and point to how well it is doing in creating jobs. It is not creating jobs as fast as the work force is growing; it has reduced unemployment by only 0.5 per cent in its period in office. It must tell the trade union movement and those who have jobs what the priorities are. It cannot have low productivity, which is what we have; full wage indexation, which is what it has now imposed; tax cuts, which is what it promises; increased government services, which is what it is also promising; increased public sector employment, which it has carried out; and generous employer funded superannuation schemes for everyone, which is apparently now the arrangement. The Government owes it to those who do not have jobs, and especially to the long term unemployed people at whom this program is directed, to take that into account. Those who have a job must consider those who do not. Job security is important to those with a job. Retirement security is important to those with a job. The maintenance of real wages is something that we cannot afford. A return to high levels of employment requires the Government to work out its priorities.

The Opposition, while supporting anything which will lift the confidence, skill and employability of the long term unemployed and those who are otherwise disadvantaged, and at whom this program is directed, is extremely anxious that in the handling of overall economic problems the Government takes the lead and tells the trade union movement what those priorities ought to be. Otherwise the people for whom this program is designed cannot benefit; labour costs can only rise; investment can only fall; jobs can be further lost. It is not very long ago that the Minister said that we were on the way to becoming the poor relation of the Asia-Pacific region. Sadly, I think that is so and, sadly, the policies being pursued, of which these people are the victims, will guarantee that that is so. It is time to call a halt. If we want support for the long term unemployed, let us get the overall priorities right in general economic policy.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The dominant and privileged position of the ACTU in the Government's decision- making, at the expense of the rest of the community.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We bring this matter of public importance before the Parliament today because there is unquestionably widespread concern in the community about the restrictive and elitist way in which this Labor Government is going about framing its Budget, its tax policy and the overall economic policy for Australia. Earlier this year the Government unilaterally decided that the Economic Planning Advisory Council, not the Government, would receive Budget submissions from the community, despite the fact that the majority of EPAC members were against this. Then, on 16 May the Hawke Government effectively shut out EPAC and the community groups making submissions to it.

SPEECH.PARA: We now know that the calling of economic summits and the establishment of bodies such as EPAC are little more than a facade, a mere window dressing behind which the real business is done. When the crunch came and the horse trading began EPAC, along with a majority of the Australian community, was shoved to one side. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) replaced them with a single interest group, namely, the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Let us make it abundantly clear: We believe that the ACTU should be consulted about economic matters. That is not at issue. But why should the Hawke Government slam the door in the face of all other groups? Was the ACTU elected to this Parliament? Of course it was not. Does it represent the wide range of community interests which are normally consulted? Of course not. It does not represent business, the ethnic community, the organised taxpayers, the 2.4 million pensioners, agriculture or large sections of the work force, to name just some. So why has this Government effectively said that some Australians are more equal than others? Why has it gone behind closed doors with trade union officials to decide matters of concern to all Australians?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pay-off.

—It would have to be some sort of pay-off beyond the linkage between the Australian Labor Party and the trade union movement. It involves not just consultation; as we were told yesterday, it involves negotiation. What right has the Cabinet to slam the door on the rest of the community, to consult with Mr Dolan and Mr Kelty and then to negotiate the nature of the Budget, tipping the whole process of our parliamentary system on its head? It is an absolutely unprecedented departure from our democratic process. Neither Mr Dolan nor Mr Kelty is responsible to this Parliament. Yet they are now in a position of influence which outweighs that of most Labor Ministers. Let us put it bluntly. This will not be Paul Keating's second Budget. It will be Cliff Dolan's first Budget and Labor's last.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, there is a lot more being settled than the forthcoming Budget. That is bad enough. Unlike this evasive and untruthful Government, at least the ACTU has made quite clear its objectives for 1984-85. It has set them out in a document called 'The Way Forward'. It has recommended radical changes which the Hawke Government will have to accept if it wants continued co-operation from the ACTU. While the Prime Minister and Mr Dolan are deciding how much tax Australians will have to pay, they are also looking at matters such as, firstly, a broadly based wealth tax; secondly, a capital gains tax and death duties; thirdly, an excess profits tax to further disrupt business investment decisions; fourthly, a radical income maintenance system supported by higher taxes; fifthly , an expanded public sector, including the socialisation of other key areas of the economy; and, sixthly, continued Government intervention in the finance sector in direct contradiction to the Campbell and Martin reports on Australia's financial system.

Of course, it matters little to this cynical Prime Minister that he was elected on a platform which mentioned none of this. He said that he was going to bring Australians together. But he shuts the door on them. He brings in only trade union representatives Mr Dolan and Mr Kelty, to negotiate the Budget! He claimed that he would pursue a program of broad consultation. In view of the way that he has gone behind closed doors with the ACTU, it is no wonder that a number of the groups which have participated in EPAC are now reviewing their options. As the President of the Australian Council of Social Service said in the wake of the last meeting of EPAC, the contributions of the ACOSS representative to that meeting were deemed 'irrelevant'. I well understand the feelings of Mr McKenzie in seeking to deal with this double-dealing Government. ACOSS was not going to endorse a document drawn up by the Prime Minister which said that pensioners were better off under the Hawke Government because the truth is, as everybody in this nation knows, that pensioners are worse off under the Hawke Government. They have been repeatedly attacked by the man who says: 'Trust me'. Trust him? Age pensioners have been persecuted by this Government through the superannuation slug, through the means test for the over-70s and now through the intrusive and discriminatory Hawke assets test.

The truth is that pensioners have already learned the true definition of Labor' s consensus approach. To this Prime Minister consensus means: 'You agree with me , or else'. The sorry fact is that EPAC is being grossly misused by the Prime Minister to pursue objectives which bear little or no resemblance to the EPAC charter. Decisions about the Budget, about taxes and about the recasting of the Australian economy are being made between two people-the Prime Minister and Mr Dolan. This puppet of a Treasurer who sits in here with the writings that he will give verse to when I have completed today is nothing but that-an abject puppet on a string of the Prime Minister and of Mr Dolan, President of the ACTU. He is quite unable day after day to answer the questions put to him by the shadow Treasurer. He set up a dorothy dixer today, reading line by line; and I assume that it was written by none other than Bill Kelty or Cliff Dolan.

The Prime Minister and Mr Dolan are the architects of the next Budget and they are carrying on that clandestine relationship which first bore fruit with the plot to stab the previous leader of the Labor Party in the back, with Dolan playing Cassius to Hawke's Brutus in that passage of play. At that crucial time Mr Dolan held back the release of Labor's economic policy so that the honourable member for Oxley, now the Minister for Foreign Minister (Mr Hayden), had no weapon with which to fight back against the challenger to his leadership. But this time they have broadened their operations. Instead of knifing a colleague they have killed the consultative process which is so important to producing a responsible Budget, and it is just not good enough to explain it away, as the Prime Minister does, by referring to a so-called special relationship.

This Government was not elected by the ACTU, yet Mr Keating and Mr Hawke dance to the tune of Mr Dolan. After all, it was the ACTU which exerted pressure on the Hawke Government and the discredited Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) to cut back the skilled labour immigration category by nearly 80 per cent and therefore contributed to this Government's upsetting of the balance of immigration categories. It was the Hawke Governemnt which caved in to the ACTU demands that ACTU affiliates be allowed to act as repositories of superannuation funds without satisfying normal prudential requirements. Trade unions do not even have an obligation to reveal their financial position, let alone have any prudential safeguards. The scope for blackmail by trade unions to force members leaving one job to place their deposit funds with the trade union if they wish to remain in the trade union is evident. The scope for unions to charge enormous fund management fees, the proceeds of which could end up financing Labor Party election campaigns on a non-disclosure basis, is clearly there.

It is the wider Australian public who are paying the price for Labor's so- called special relationship with the ACTU, and that price is too high. The ordinary Australian now knows that Labor is not governing in his or her interests. The Hawke Government is not interested in what ordinary people have to say. It could not care less. As long as it locks itself in with Mr Dolan and Mr Kelty it feels that it has done its duty, not to consult but to negotiate. It is trade union concerns and aspirations, in dealings with the trade union bosses , that are uppermost in the minds of this Government. It will not get away with it because, apart from disregarding the desires, needs and aspirations of the broader community, it is also another anti-business step. Already it has imposed a resource rent tax. Already it has proposed changes to the Trade Practices Act, another example of the Hawke Government bowing to union pressure.

The wage fixing system, with full indexation, has further eroded our industrial and export competitiveness. Despite what the Prime Minister claimed in this Parliament, the chances of minimal wage rises over the next year are non- existent. There have already been several successful attempts to avoid the prices and incomes accord. The Hawke Government abjectly supports the superannuation ploy, an absolute phoney, in the building industry. The Prices Surveillance Authority will further interfere with the market-place.

As well as harming business, this cosy arrangement between the Prime Minister and Mr Dolan excludes the most vulnerable in our community from direct representation in the budgetary process. Of course, we have already seen how this Government deals with Australia's 2.4 million pensioners. It does not deal with them at all. It just dumps it on them. Why should the pensioners be ignored in the framing of the Budget? Perhaps they do not have the sort of industrial muscle which makes the Prime Minister jump. Perhaps they cannot intrude into the New South Wales Right and exert pressure on Mr Keating, with all his cohorts with their chequered backgrounds and current devious activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman will refer to the Treasurer by his title.

—Perhaps pensioners do not have the clout that the New South Wales Right has with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and his chequered associates in that motley mob. Perhaps they do not have the voting power within the ALP but they have the voting power from which the Prime Minister will suffer and learn about when he calls his premature election. Cutting off the great majority of Australians from having a hearing on the economy is totally wrong.
—They certainly don't have any foreshore land.

—No. I noted the Treasurer's difficulty in answering the honourable member's questions on interest rates. Perhaps we could ask him, when he is speaking, whether he can tell us the current interest rates on foreshore land. The cost to Australia of the Hawke-Dolan special relationship-I emphasise ' special relationship'-will be enormous in areas such as overall economic management. The bottom line on the surrender of wages policy to the ACTU and now the handing over of a major part of fiscal policy to it. Is that the development and implementation of a long term economic policy for Australia is now virtually impossible. The Government has sold out Australians and their prospects of long term prosperity in exchange for a short term, back door political deal. It is the sort of deal in which the Treasurer has been involved in his grubby political life. Throughout his political career there have been back door, nefarious deals and they are on again now, but not on behalf of the Australian Labor Party.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will remember standing orders 74, 75 and 76 and not impute motives.

—I speak of nothing else, Madam Deputy Speaker. I know them well. I would recite them for you but there is not enough time. I do recall them well. The fact is that the nefarious, dirty-handed dealings that have gone on under this man in his operations with the Australian Labor Party are just what is happening to the Australian community now. There is a deal with the unions but no deal with the Australian people. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer claim a special relationship with the ACTU and say that it will result in three benefits -wage restraint, the ability to pursue an expansionary fiscal policy and low industrial unrest. When one examines those three benefits one sees that they all fall to the ground. This is a sectional government which puts the interests of a minority ahead of the majority, and Australians will not stand for it. The Government must stop misusing EPAC. It is time all Australians, and not just the ACTU, had a say through the consultative mechanism on taxes and the Budget. If the Government continues this sort of conniving with the trade union movement, the Government might do its deal with it but a deal will be done against the Government by the Australian people.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is precisely because of that sort of inane contribution that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) is now rating as low as any Leader of the Opposition has ever rated in the polls. If we want to see a bumper issue of a poll which rates the Leader of the Opposition low we have only to see today's Bulletin poll, which will confirm it more than anything else. The ridiculous charge in this matter of public importance is that the Australian Council of Trade Unions has a dominant and privileged position in the Government's decision-making. The Government rejects that proposal out of hand. The only decisions which are taken by this Government are taken appropriately in the Government processes in the Cabinet room.

SPEECH.PARA: I reject absolutely the claim that the Economic Planning Advisory Council is shut out of negotiations or discussions about the Budget processes or the economy. When did we ever see the Liberal Party of Australia consult business about a strategy behind a Budget, about an economic situation, as the Government did at the National Economic Summit Conference last year and as it does now in discussions with EPAC? This alternative government never had that as a government. The best it could do was have single, narrow sectional interests arriving for their handouts after the Budget strategy, so-called, had already been fixed. It has no idea of running an economy and it never had. What we have now is a consultative process and the consultation, of course, extends beyond the economy. The Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, had consultations with the motor vehicle industry about the car plan. I have had extensive consultations on the report of the Martin Review of the Australian Financial System with various elements of the financial sector. The same applies to the insurance industry. I have had extensive consultations with the insurance industry on the insurance legislation amendments. The Government has had consultations on the economy with many groups. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and I have had extensive discussions with the Business Council of Australia in session. There have been discussions with the Confederation of Australian Industry and the National Farmers Federation. Right across the board there has been that consultation. Of course there has been consultation with the ACTU. The ACTU gets the respect which it warrants because of the close and co-operative relationship it has with the Government.

Two major flaws in the Opposition's attack are that it has misrepresented the purposes of the working party which has been established between the Government and the ACTU in respect of taxation and it misunderstands the ACTU's role in the prices and incomes accord. The Leader of the Opposition talked about horse trading. Who is the beneficiary of the horse trading, as he calls it? The beneficiaries are all of the corporate interests across Australia which will no longer be facing a wages bill which will chop off their profit growth and chop off the recovery. What the last Government gave them was an increase in average weekly earnings of 45 per cent in three years, an 8 per cent increase in real terms, and a 4 per cent increase in real unit labour costs. That is what the previous Government gave them and they know it. The Leader of the Opposition and his Party are held in such low esteem in the public opinion polls and by business because they know they had no policy. It is all right talking about wage restraint in a recession, but what about wage restraint in a recovery? The former Government has never had an incomes policy and it is incapable of having an incomes policy because it always attacks the one group with which it must speak to secure some agreements on incomes, and that group is the ACTU.

The Leader of the Opposition, who is leaving the chamber now, has never taken any interest in the domestic economy. In the years when the Fraser Government was in office he, as Foreign Minister, was swanning around the United States of America with Shirley MacLaine or trying to crash one of Ted Kennedy's parties on the east coast of the United States. That is what he was all about. He was trying to play statesman. When he came back he stayed away from the hard subjects. He spat out the dummy before he even got it into his mouth. He was quite happy to allow the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) to front up in this place year after year in a recession, while he swanned around, and then he made a cowardly attack upon the former Prime Minister before slinking back into his Cabinet, taking up the portfolio of industry and commerce. When did we ever see any deregulation from the Leader of the Opposition in industry and commerce? It is a joke. The car industry was in a shambles when he left the portfolio, as was the steel industry. What about industrial relations? As I have said, the Leader of the Opposition spat out that dummy quickly. There was no way that he would stay in industrial relations. That is one of the reasons why he resigned. The pressure was too much. He has never had any experience.

If the honourable member thinks that in Australian business there is a morsel of confidence in his capacity to deal with economic problems he is mistaken. What we have here is an intellectual rust bucket. The bucket might be painted up , but there is rust underneath the duco. That is well understood by everybody in Australian business. Everybody of significance in Australian business takes the Leader of the Opposition with a grain of salt in terms of the serious contribution which he could make in running the economy. He dares to compare himself with the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) as the potential Prime Minister of this country. Of course, that is simply a joke.

The fact of life is that we now have in place an economic and incomes policy which can guarantee this country growth at the same time as a decline in inflation-a pick-up in profits and a pick-up in spending and investment. Of course, the Australian Council of Trade Unions played a principal role in that historic accord between this Party and itself. Of course, the ACTU has an honoured role, but it is not a privileged role. It is no more privileged than the role accorded the Business Council of Australia, the Economic Planning and Advisory Council or any other group to discuss these issues.

What about, for instance, the ACTU's role in respect of superannuation? If the Government was so compliant, as the honourable gentleman suggests, obviously we would not be passing the superannuation tax amendments, because they did not meet with the favour of the ACTU. Of course, it is just a phoney suggestion that in some way this Government is at the beck and call of the ACTU. We consult the ACTU, as indeed all governments should. Indeed, I believe that even in 1982 the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee), who is sitting at the table opposite me, consulted with the ACTU about tax reform in that year's Budget. Well he might have done so. I do not cavil at that at all. I think that is entirely reasonable. In fact, what we are doing is to look at the options which are available in the economic area. The decisions in respect of tax, the shape of the Budget and its parameters will be determined by the Government, as is entirely proper. There will not be any determining of those issues outside of government.

Of course, all the coalition knows about is division. All we saw in the Fraser years under the leadership of that gentleman and the members of his front bench, many of whom are now in opposition and who will remain in opposition for much longer, was division. That is all we ever saw. Even now when in opposition we see the Liberal Party of Australia relying upon the divisive issue of racism, as it relied on other divisive issues in the past to divide the Australian community. It is a disgrace that the Opposition, after so many years of bipartisanship even on that policy, should have abandoned its position and sought to retreat to that issue of racism for some sectional advantage.

What we have here is misrepresentation and mock indignation about the basis of the Government's relationship with the ACTU. What underpins this is a fear of the operation of the prices and incomes accord. The Opposition fears that because it knows that its success will guarantee Australia a non-inflationary recovery which will restore Australia to reasonable levels of economic growth and ameliorate those high levels of inflation. Of course, that is what Australia has never been able to do. In the years since the scourge of inflation touched this country-particularly in the years of the coalition governments-we never saw any attempt to look at economic policy in the longer term. There was no attempt to consult the major players in the game, whether it be business or the unions. What we had was policy handed down from on high-an expedient policy at that- designed for the next election only, with no consideration of the longer term. It was all about the next election.

Of course, it is a joke that the Leader of the Opposition is talking about the ACTU's role in Budget policy. In the 1982 Budget the Treasurer never even had a role in Budget policy. Neither the honourable member for Bennelong nor the Treasury had a role in Budget policy in 1982. The Budget was determined by the then Prime Minister who went for the most sleezy changes in fiscal policy to try to secure his re-election as Prime Minister, to look after his miserable political hide. Consequently we saw things such as payment of an interest subsidy to home owners who had had mortgages for years when the real cost of those mortgages had declined. That was a disgraceful measure put into the 1982 Budget. I know that that was against the wishes of the former Treasurer. That is how consultative things were in those days. Not even the Treasurer got a look in on the shape of Budgets. We all know that. In fact, I think the honourable member for Bennelong found out about the 1982 Budget in one of Laurie Oakes's columns. That is the way consultation took place in that Government.

Now we have a government sitting down with EPAC. It has discussions as good as any this nation has ever had. At each of its meetings it looks at all the ramifications of economic policy. The Government is sitting down with trade unions, small business, local government, consumers, the Australian Council of Social Service and the farmers, talking about the problems which confront this country and trying to find consensus through that. At the same time we have that information and those views permeating the major business groups and the ACTU.

It is unbelievable that the Opposition should cavil at this process. It is unbelievable that the Opposition should cavil at having these major bodies brought into discussions on economic policy. It would be quite easy for the Prime Minister and me to sit back and say: 'We have been elected to power. We will consult nobody. It is our right to hand the tablets down from the mount and just read out the Budget in August and let everybody find out about it that way' . Of course, we consult because we want a strategy that will stick together in a recovery. When we see the growth coming up we want to ensure that it is not frittered away and aborted in another round of prices and wages increases.

We do not sit back, as the Opposition did when in government, and say: 'Here comes a mining boom; we do not have to try any more. Let us have market determined wages'. Under that Government we had a wages explosion and another bout of massive inflation. We had 11.5 per cent inflation when the rest of the world had 5 per cent and we had unemployment rocketing by another quarter of a million people. That is why the Opposition was turned out of office. That is why the Opposition will stay out of office. The Opposition will not deter this Government at all in its discussions with the ACTU. It is an honourable relationship which we have with it, but it is a relationship with a clear understanding that the prerogatives of government reside with the Government and that the decisions are taken in Cabinet and not in any other body.

To add insult to injury, we have this Leader of the Opposition, the leader of a divisive party, who stands for nothing. He does not even stand by some of the things he said when he was in government. He represents nothing and nobody. People in business know it; the public knows it. That is being registered in the opinion polls. The Leader of the Opposition has never been near the economy. We would think that in all the years the Leader of the Opposition was the show pony of the Liberal Party he would have accepted an important portfolio in the economic area. The only portfolios he had that related to the economy were those concerning industrial relations and business which, of course, he gave up very quickly because they were too hard. They were not for him. They were not for the show pony. He wanted to get back on the 747 to hightail it to Washington to check into the cocktail party circuits-that is when he was not standing at the mirror running a little dye through his hair.

We are not interested in the views of painted, perfumed gigolos. We are not interested in the Gucci image and the rest. We are interested in making Australia work. We are interested in making this economy tick over. We will do it with business, the ACTU and every other group. We will not be deterred from our magnificent obsession which is to consult with every group in this community that matters to try to get a consensus approach to policy, including economic policy, to restore this country to the greatness it once knew, before the Liberals. We will not be deterred from that course. That is why we reject this matter of public importance absolutely and out of hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition parties believe very strongly in consultation. When in government we consulted, prior to the preparation of the Budget, with all of the interested parties, but we did not give anyone a position of privilege. That is the purpose of this matter of public importance today. The prices and incomes accord does not represent consensus. It is an understanding, in fact, between the political and industrial wings of the labour movement. That is not consensus, that is an expedient political accommodation. Why is the Australian Council of Trade Unions camped outside the doors of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating)? The reason is found in the accord. Page 7 of that document states:

SPEECH.PARA: There must be continuous consultation and co-operation between the parties involved.
That is, of course, the Government and the ACTU. No other party in the community is interested in the outcome of the Budget. The document also states:
Government policy at all levels should be accommodating and supportive.

I repeat that: It is Government policy which must be accommodating and supportive of the trade unions and not the other way round. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) said, the community elects the government to provide the leadership; it does not elect the trade union movement. If any good is to come from the accord and if anything ought to be accommodating and supportive, it is the trade unions which should be accommodating and supportive of government after they have given advice.

We believe in consultation. The Treasurer is right that as the Minister I practised that with the ACTU, as I did with the employers. However, it is one thing to take its views into account and allow them to express strongly and considerately their views on policy. It is quite another thing to give them a position of influence which is different from that of others. That is demonstrably what is happening at the moment. Currently, the ACTU is being heard to the exclusion of the interests of other Australians, and that is dangerous. It is also undemocratic. It is a question of unions having a greater degree of influence with governments than we have ever had in this country before. Saying that is not indulging in union bashing, it is merely criticising the accord, and validly so. Consultation by governments with a view to gaining consensus is obviously commendable and is desired by the community, but consensus is not always possible.

What happens when consultation identifies the areas of disagreement and governments then have to make decisions? Under the accord, the Government is to be accommodating and supportive of the trade union movement and not the other way round. In the previous debate I observed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) that when inevitably he disagrees with the ACTU and the Australian Clerical Officers Association over staffing levels in the Commonwealth Employment Service, the trade unions, in the interests of the unemployed, will have to lift their bans on the unemployed and accept the Government's decision or the Government will have to make a decision and abide by it in a way that protects the interests of the long term unemployed. That means that it will not be accommodating and supportive. In fact it will have to lead, and that is what the community expects of it. Consultation is one thing; leadership where disagreements occur is another.

The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has admitted defeat on unemployment. A document released by his Department last week speaks of unacceptable levels of unemployment being a fact of life for the next decade at least. In the presentation he gave today on the community employment program he repeated those sentiments. That is not the view the Opposition takes. All the assumptions which are held across the range of the labour market and the management of the economy have to be re-examined in order to get policies that create the maximum level of private sector investment and the maximum growth in the economy and, therefore, employment opportunities. That is not the advice or the influence coming from the ACTU to the Government today.

I recall the present Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, when he was only the honourable member for Gellibrand, saying on occasions that Labor had a good chance of not being elected as long as the trade unions were difficult and militant. The way of overcoming that problem seems to have been to form the accord, which was then sold to the public on the basis that it represented consensus. Because of the obligation to be accommodating and supportive, what is given in the name of consensus is at great cost to all. Some of those not involved in that consensus, some of those not with that privileged opportunity-the long term unemployed and the investors of capital, who are the only means of really creating permanent employment-are not consulted. They are expected to pay for it. In the preparation of this Budget, in spite of what the Treasurer has said, the Business Council of Australia, the Chamber of Automotive Industries and other bodies are not being given the same access to information and the same privilege for advice. The business representatives on the Economic Planning and Advisory Council are certainly not able to go back and discuss with their organisations the information they get from the Government at EPAC. Yet the ACTU Executive can receive that information from its advisers. So the ACTU is in a privileged position and has even canvassed publicly those areas of tax cuts that will be acceptable to it.

There is one more area in which the Government has bowed to pressure from the ACTU in a way that is demonstrably not in the interests of the public. I refer to industrial relations policy and, in particular, the repeal of section 45D of the Trade Practices Act. An undertaking was given by the Government, even though members of the Government are aware that the Business Council of Australia, the CAI and the other employer bodies are very strongly opposed to it and have been advising the Government not to repeal that legislation. The Government itself has misgivings, and both the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and the Prime Minister have indicated those misgivings on occasions. What sort of consensus is it, what sort of consultation procedure is it, when the employers of this country, who have been very co-operative with this Government in a responsible way, are saying: 'Do not repeal this legislation'? Not only is the Government planning to repeal that legislation, which is the only effective legislation protecting industry and commerce against secondary boycotts, but also it is planning to appeal all rights under the common law. That is the direct result of representations by the ACTU. Those are the reasons why we say that the ACTU holds a privileged position.

The proposal in the Government's discussion paper to outlaw common law remedies in this area is really a denial of natural justice. It is an unwarranted attack on the right of employers to protect their businesses and the jobs of their own employees. The Opposition will do everything in its power to see that this pernicious proposal is resisted and defeated at every turn. The important point to know is that section 45D has provided businesses with prompt and effective protection against the abuse of monopoly power by unions in the areas of secondary boycotts. That means that people who are not involved in a dispute with their employees are the victims of disputes because of the power of certain unions to impose secondary boycotts. No other means have worked in Australia. By their very nature, secondary boycotts are really beyond traditional employer- employee relationships. Therefore, it has been seen to be appropriate that they should be administered under the Trade Practices Act. There have been quite a number of examples of the success of that legislation. One remembers that during the last election campaign the scissors lift dispute was resolved because of the pressure of section 45D applications. One of the reasons why a greater level of peace has been returned to the transport industry is the existence of this legislation and its potential to break secondary boycotts.

The Government's case for removing section 45D is false. There is no case for removing it, apart from the Government's agreement with the ACTU to be accommodating and supportive on all occasions. The ACTU says: 'We want 45D repealed. We want the common law repealed, in spite of what that does to innocent third parties or the people who are employed by them. We want that out. We don't want curbs on the unions.' That is accommodated and supported by the Government. It says 'Right, out it goes', in spite of the consultation and the advice it gets from the employers. The Government has provided no evidence whatsoever to support its claim that sections 45D and 45E are, in its words, ' potentially highly disruptive to Australian industrial relations'. Nowhere has it demonstrated that. On the contrary, the experience of the existence of that section, plus the common law right, is that it is potentially in the interests of Australian industrial relations, unit labour costs and our international competitiveness and, therefore, our capacity to employ people. So on the contrary, the Government admits again, and I quote its own paper on section 45D, that penalties have never been imposed', 'damages are not the principal objective', and 'in virtually all cases the matter is settled without an interim injunction being made absolute'. It is the very fact that the legislation exists that brings that result about. That is the very reason why it should be retained .

The assertion by the Government that sections 45D and 45E do nothing to resolve disputes is nonsense. In fact, they prevent those disputes arising. They prevent the boycotts of innocent parties who are not involved in disputes. Therefore, they help to save their businesses and the jobs of the people. That is what we are concerned about. The commitment of the Government to be accommodating and supportive when the Australian Council of Trade Unions asks for something, such as repealing penalties for industrial action, is not in the public interest, is not consensus and is not, in fact, a question of fair consultation. It lifts that body to a position of privilege never before seen in the history of this country.

DEBATE.TITLE: PURCHASE OF AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING FACILITIES BY THE COMMONWEALTH

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That, in accordance with paragraph 8 (1) (d) of the Public Service Accounts Committee Act 1951, this House refers to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for investigation and report as necessary from time to time, the proposed purchase of automatic data processing facilities by the Commonwealth, or any department or authority of the Commonwealth staffed under the Public Service Act 1922, notification of intention of which is to be conveyed to the Committee by the Minister responsible for the intending purchaser.
(2) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of the resolution and requesting its concurrence.

The passing of the motion now before the House will enable revised procedures to be introduced that will not only provide a mechanism for independent scrutiny of major individual ADP acquisition proposals by the Commonwealth but also remove the timing and other practical difficulties that currently arise in enmeshing the detailed consideration of these often complex proposals with the Budget process. There has, of course, been some change in recent years in the procedures governing computer acquisition. In particular, the fairly severe and time consuming central controls that applied to all computer and related purchases have been relaxed to a degree. Authority was given for acquisitions costing less than $2m to be approved by individual Ministers or for those costing less than $1m to be approved by departmental permanent heads subject always, of course, to funds availability. However, purchases over $2m currently have to be submitted for approval as new policy in the Budget context and so receive attention by Ministers at the same time as a host of other proposals coming forward and competing for allocation from a restricted supply of funds.

This really pinpoints the problem with the present acquisition policy. Given the extent to which computers have become an essential tool in the administration process, some relatively routine purchases can exceed $2m. However, from time to time some very large acquisition proposals come forward which are of such complexity and raise such important related issues that they cannot be dealt with adequately under existing procedures, which require proposals to be considered under the severe pressures imposed by the Budget timetable. There may, for example, be global factors involved in such proposals which may not be adequately addressed in the necessarily brief format of submissions considered in Budget deliberations.

The Government proposes therefore to address this difficulty by enabling such issues to be scrutinised at an earlier stage and well before the commitment of financial and other resources. For example, some major issues which need further and independent scrutiny include the following points:
Employment

Employment considerations are a matter of serious concern. This applies not only to the redundancy issue but also to potential effects upon the structure of the job market, identification of the need for new skills and the provision of appropriate education and re-training facilities.
Australian Industry Participation

I have seen projections which suggest that the information sector is likely to become one of the largest sectors of employment in the economy by the turn of the century and that the computer industry may well be the largest in the world by that time. Clearly in these circumstances we should make every effort to ensure that the Government's purchase of hardware and software encourages significant Australian industry participation.
Industrial Issues

Apart from employment considerations and encouragement of local industry there are industrial issues which need to be considered, including due attention to the working environment, ergonomic factors and so on which are of concern from an industrial relations/occupational health viewpoint.

Additionally there are specific matters which must be addressed to determine the extent to which an individual proposal is likely to achieve worthwhile objectives commensurate with the financial and other resources applied to it. Any objective scrutiny of proposals must include an assessment of the following:
Needs

ADP objectives and work programs must be aligned towards the attainment of authorised departmental programs and objectives. Each individual proposal should be assessed in this context and even though a proposal may have merit in its own right, it is important for comparison purposes to assess the relative merits of alternatives in order to ensure that the proposal presents the most effective and productive solution to a particular problem. In this area, independent and impartial assessment is of particular value.
Cost Effectiveness

In many instances it is difficult to attribute dollar amounts to qualitative benefits. It is nevertheless important to assess the effectiveness of a proposal in terms which readily convey a sense of value. Public money should not only be spent effectively but also be seen to be spent effectively.
Risks

As well as the consideration of risks and constraints associated with introduction of technologically advanced products, independent scrutiny will provide an appropriate means of assessing the viability or otherwise of proposed implementation timetables and resultant expenditure programs.

The new procedures are designed to ensure that departments and authorities apply themselves assiduously to the planning process. The early submission of a proposal arising from that planning and the consideration of the proposal will be early steps along a path leading to the eventual acquisition of computing facilities. The essential review and independent scrutiny processes will thus be completed before any major commitment of public moneys is made, thereby safeguarding the interests of the taxpayer and, at the same time, conserving the resources of the computer industry. I am confident that the ability to bring forward submissions at any time, not just in the Budget context, will offset the time spent on independent scrutiny.

Against this background and after careful consideration of alternatives by the Government, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts is considered the most appropriate and well placed body to undertake review function. The JCPA is well established and has in the past conducted investigations in the automatic data processing field. It has a current role in oversighting the Department of Social Security's ADP project. In making this proposal the Government is not asking the JCPA to review Government decisions. The objective is to allow Parliament, through its Committee, to form a judgment and provide advice before the decision is taken. The Government recognises the additional work load this will entail for the Committee and requests that the House provide adequate additional resources necessary to ensure that the important task of scrutinising proposals involving significant public expenditure may be conducted efficiently.
