SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to establish procedures for assessing and, where appropriate, authorising biological control programs in Australia. Complementary legislation will be passed by the State and Northern Territory Parliaments to establish a uniform and equitable system, applying throughout Australia, which will ensure that biological control programs that have been identified as being in the public interest can proceed in accordance with law and without interruption by litigation. The need for this Bill was recognised in June 1983, when an injunction was obtained which prevented the release of insects to control Echium, a plant commonly known as Paterson's Curse or Salvation Jane. Echium has long been perceived as a noxious weed in south-eastern Australia and is commonly declared as such. Its control by biological means was considered both desirable and possible by the agencies which have responsibility for these matters, and whose integrity and expertise have never before been questioned.

Two beekeepers and two graziers who believed the plant had beneficial qualities obtained the injunction on the grounds of the common law of private nuisance, which is concerned more with the rights of the individual than the question of public interest. It became clear that there were two related problems. First, there was no provision in existing legislation which authorised the release of control agents, such as insects or rusts, into the environment. Secondly, it was clear that there was no equitable means of resolving a conflict of interests concerning biological control programs with a view to establishing public benefit. In developing the legislation to resolve the legal status of biological control, it has been necessary to address both of these problems. Before I advert to specific features of the Bill, I would like to make a few general points about biological control and the purpose of the Bill. Biological control has had a long and honourable history in Australia. In addition to its well known successes in controlling rabbits and prickly pear, biological control has also helped to account for numerous agricultural pests, for environmentally unacceptable plants such as water weeds and for vectors of disease such as mosquitos.

The Bill will not affect the existing basic scientific, technical or safety procedures and standards applying to biological control. Decisions concerning proposed biological control programs will continue to observe these fully. The Bill does not in any way reduce the effect of relevant Acts, which include the Quarantine Act, the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act and the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act. The Bill is not directed against any particular weed or pest, but rather provides the means of deciding whether or not the control of individual weeds or pests would be in the public interest. There is no requirement for all proposed biological control programs to be submitted for consideration in terms of the Bill. The great majority are not a potential source of controversy and agencies may prefer to proceed independently. However, where an agency wishes to pursue an independent course of action it will remain subject to existing legislation, standards and procedures and, of course, subject to litigation on a common law basis.

This Bill will be complemented by legislation in the States and the Northern Territory. The targets of biological control and the agents which control the targets are not familiar with political boundaries. As the majority of biological control programs are directed at agricultural pests or weeds, the Bill provides that the Australian Agricultural Council will have primary responsibility for taking the actions and making the decisions referred to in the Bill. Where appropriate, the Council will seek the advice and assistance of relevant bodies, such as the Australian Forestry Council and the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers. The proposed role of the Australian Agricultural Council is appropriate in that it represents all States, is concerned with agriculture and is the vehicle by which most biological control proposals are presently considered. In order to create a legal entity for the purposes of the Act, there is provision for the establishment of a Biological Control Authority in the Australian Capital Territory. Complementary legislation will establish similar authorities in the States and the Northern Territory. At the first meeting of the AAC each year the Commonwealth Minister in consultation with State Ministers shall designate the Commonwealth Minister or one of the State Ministers as the Australia-wide Biological Control Authority.

The provisions of the Bill may be broken down into a few essential elements. First, public opinion concerning a proposed biological activity will be widely canvassed. Second, depending on the nature of any public comment, an inquiry may be held. Finally, based on the information available, including the report of a public inquiry in the event of one being held, the program may be declared in terms of the Act and biological control agents may then be released. A declared program will protect those authorised to conduct the program from any legal action for damages and will preclude the opportunity to halt the program by means of a common law injunction. However, as with other areas of Government decision making, judgments relating to particular biological control programs could result in gains and losses to various groups in the community. Losses could be experienced by the honey industry, for instance, if a decision were made to proceed with a control program against echium. While it is desirable that the greater public benefit take precedence, it is also necessary to recognise the concerns of those adversely affected. Thus the Bill allows for fair and equitable decision making processes which provide the opportunity for the question of assistance to those claiming to be adversely affected to be addressed.

Turning to the procedural aspects, the Bill obliges all proposed targets to be advertised, but there is a discretion as to whether the proposed agents should be advertised. The target is a weed or a pest and there is no difficulty for a lay member of the public to express a view as to whether they perceive the target to be undesirable or beneficial. Once the target is declared, the basis on which an agent such as an insect capable of controlling the target is selected is essentially technical, is subject to the requirements of the Quarantine Act and is less amenable to judgment by lay persons. Where the agent has been deemed safe in terms of the Quarantine Act there are grounds for assuming that a public inquiry is unnecessary. Nevertheless, an inquiry as to the desirability of a proposed agent still remains an option under this Bill. The Bill provides that a target must have been declared as such before agents to control that target can be declared or released. However, the Bill also allows the nomination and resolution of proposed targets and their respective agents as well as public hearings to proceed simultaneously.

The basis of, and options for, public inquiry are essentially the same for target and agent proposals. The Biological Control Authority, after considering the information available and consulting the Council, may order an inquiry if it considers person or the environment will be adversely affected. The Bill provides for different forms of inquiry, which reflects the fact that biological control may have different social, economic or environmental consequences.

Declaration of a target or agent is the final step in the process of consultation and public decision making for which this Bill provides. Declaration is made where the Authority is satisfied that control of a target would be for the public benefit. Once a target and the relevant agent or agents have been declared, the agents may be released subject to any conditions specified. As I have already indicated, the Bill provides that no legal proceedings shall be instituted where the release of agents is in accordance with the Act.

In clearly specified emergency conditions, the Bill provides that the Authority may declare target or agent organisms as such without first observing the requirements concerning public comment or inquiry which I have outlined. Such emergencies are rare but, as the recent outbreak of lucerne aphid demonstrated, the relevant agencies need to be able to respond quickly to prevent what would otherwise involve considerable economic loss and disruption.

There are a number of existing biological control programs in Australia and these will be declared in terms of the Bill. This simply reflects the fact that the existence of a successful biological control program is a fact of life. In the absence of any previous legal challenge it must be assumed that they are sanctioned by the public. Nevertheless, the Bill provides that any developments in existing programs, such as the introduction of a new sort of biological control agent, may be subject to its provisions.

There are several provisions in the Bill which enable the Commonwealth Act and the complementary State and Northern Territory legislation to operate efficiently. These are directed at ensuring that where all the provisions of the Commonwealth Act have been fulfilled, a declaration in terms of that Act applies in all the States and the Northern Territory. This avoids having to duplicate applications, advertisements and inquiries. I should point out that while all the States and the Northern Territory have co-operated fully in the development of this legislation, there may be one or two matters of detail which could require amendments to the Bill at a later stage.

It is not possible to quantify the financial impact of the Bill accurately. Effective biological control is accepted as a highly cost-effective means of regulating weeds and pests and has the capacity to save millions of dollars for rural industries. Direct costs are associated with the cost of advertisements and public inquiries, but the frequency and nature of these costs will largely be determined by events that arise on an irregular basis. If past experience is to be used as a guide, biological control very rarely causes controversy and it could be expected that public inquiries would therefore also be rare. However, provision for public comment may lead to increased awareness of biological control programs and hence to more inquiries. The Bill institutes a number of additional administrative requirements. These may involve indirect costs to various existing committees concerned with biological control. Direct costs to the Commonwealth for salaries and administration will be less than $100,000 per annum.

There has been considerable pressure, from the rural sector in particular, to resolve urgently the legal status of biological control. While most of this concern relates to the biological control of echium, the legislation has been developed to resolve equitably conflict concerning any biological control program on the basis of public benefit. I draw the attention of honourable members to recent events in Victoria. Biological control of blackberry in that State, in New South Wales and in Tasmania has long been a subject of controversy but there was no means of resolving that controversy. In the end, someone illegally introduced a rust capable of controlling blackberry. This action not only contravened the Quarantine Act, but also was done without the necessary safeguards to protect other plant species.

This Bill does not seek to meddle with existing scientific or quarantine measures, or to impose priorities. It does provide what should be a publicly acceptable and equitable means of determining whether a proposed biological control program is in the public interest. Once public benefit is established, then a program can proceed in the full knowledge that it will benefit the community without imposing unacceptable consequences on the economy or the environment. I commend this Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall keep my remaining remarks on the Bill very brief. In the 1972-73 financial year, just over $2 billion was spent on social security programs, or 20.6 per cent of total Budget outlays in that year. A decade later, in the 1982-83 financial year, more than $14 billion was spent on social security programs, representing almost 30 per cent of total Budget outlays. Given the obvious importance of this level of national expenditure and the unquestionable significance of the needs of six million Australians who are the recipients of some types of social security assistance, it becomes essential that the operative legislation is framed in appropriate and equable terms. SPEECH.PARA: There is one major aspect of this legislation which is of great interest to me and to the constitutents in the Federal electorate of Bendigo. Amendments to the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act will bring into being a vital new policy initiative and fulfil a pre-election promise made by the Australian Labor Party to the frail aged and the disabled and their families. As part of our Government 's commitment to redress the imbalance between institutional and community care for the aged and the disabled, an initiative announced in last year's Budget, provides financial incentives or short term respite accommodation for aged and disabled persons who are cared for in a community setting, such as the family home. The Bill gives effect to that initiative.

The new respite care subsidy scheme will be open to non-profit organisations which maintain beds within their residential units for the purpose of short term relief or respite care. Initially hostels of up to 50 beds will be expected to keep at least one bed for respite care and hostels with over 50 beds will need to maintain at least two of those beds. Such a scheme surely reflects the concern felt by this Government for the quality of life of the aged and disabled in our community. To date respite care services and community support services aimed at assisting aged and disabled people to live in the community have been extremely limited.

In my electorate of Bendigo the urgent need for these services, especially respite care services, has been clearly stated by the Bendigo Disabled Persons Support Group, an organisation representing physically disabled adults and their relatives and carers. In a survey of disabled people undertaken in 1981 by that group it was found that as many as 50 severely physically disabled adults in the Bendigo area were in need of short term relief accommodation. A little more than a month ago, I was delighted to be able to convey a decision of the Minister for Social Security that the Bendigo Disabled Persons Support Group had received a grant of more than $168,000 to establish a respite care hostel for disabled persons in the electorate of Bendigo. This hostel will have the capacity to accommodate up to 10 adults for short term relief accommodation.

There is no doubt that the hostel represents a breakthrough achievement for both the disabled people of Bendigo and aged and disabled people throughout Australia. This hostel in Bendigo will give physically disabled people and their families the chance to achieve greater independence of lifestyle while maintaining their important family and community base of care. Equally there is no doubt that the hostel's operation as a wholly relief accommodation service will be greatly assisted by the respite care subsidy scheme.

In closing, I remind the House that, however small the individual changes and initiatives contained in this Bill may seem, when viewed in total they represent an important set of amendments. The Bill represents a commitment to socially appropriate and equitable social welfare measures in every detail of their administration and delivery. I commend the Bill to the House.

It is dreadful that people who appear to be sympathetic to the needs of the elderly have moved to create circumstances in which cupboards, drawers and the utmost of intimate personal possessions may have to be examined to see whether false declarations have been made. It is a frightening thing that is facing the people in my electorate. They have been forewarned. I have not been neglectful in telling them what to expect. We will shortly see an unpredictable and unjustified impost on thousands of Australian pensioners.

Mr Deputy Speaker, whilst your unbiased attitudes are held up by all as being the pinnacle of responsibility for a person in your high office, I know that you too in your heart feel as I do and will reject the assets test.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member is going too far. His time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certain it would be true to say that all members of this House share a genuine compassion for those in the community who are less fortunate than we are. I am certain that under successive governments, including the present Government, everything is done to try to help those people in the community who, for circumstances which at times are beyond their control, are not able to properly and adequately care for themselves. However, I think that in the circumstances that are encroaching on us in this country we cannot properly debate the social security problems that confront people without also considering the economic impact that social security and other costs of government are having. Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask you and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) for some leniency in the comments I want to make because I want to relate the effects of the Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill before us today to their impact on the economy. I suggest that in order to have a balanced debate on any social security or other matter that comes before this House the economic impact must also be taken into account.
—The honourable member for Wilmot must address his remarks to the Bill.

—My remarks will be addressed to the Bill. Mr Deputy Speaker, if we study the provisions in this Bill-I am sure all of us can find individual cases where anomalies do occur in various social welfare programs and the Minister in his compassion is trying to remove some of them-we see that their overall effect will increase the total social security cost. We cannot ignore that. I am quite certain that the Minister would have had representations made to him, as do all members of parliament, pointing out anomalies. When there is a certain cut-off point under social security programs some people, for whatever reason, just miss out. It is obviously those cases that the Minister is trying to include in the various programs. However, I remind the Minister that if one draws a line in any program there will always be people who are just on the other side of that line. So, while he may think that in this Bill he is tidying up some anomalies, really he is creating another set of anomalies. Those other anomalies will inevitably occur.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is designed to overcome what one identifies now as anomalies but it will have the effect of increasing the total cost of social security upon the taxpayers. What it will also do is create another set of anomalies which, if one tries to overcome them, will also again increase the cost of social security. The social security costs facing the Government, and therefore the taxpayer, are rising at the moment at such an astronomical rate that we cannot continue to ignore them in any debate on social security that occurs in this House.

I understand the compassion the Minister has for people in the community who are less fortunate but I remind him that figures produced by the Department of the Treasury over the period 1981-82 to 1986-87 reveal that the total cost of social security will rise from $11,501m to a projected $21,600m in 1986-87. The figure will almost double over a five-year period. With the economy we have in Australia regardless of the compassion that we may have, we cannot continue to ignore the cost of social security on the Budget and on taxpayers.

I understand that the Government wants to help people who are affected by anomalies relating to the unemployment benefit, the single parents benefit, or whatever. However, if the cumulative effect is to run the economy of this country to a point where we can no longer pay our social security bill, I remind the House that not just those people who are affected by the present anomalies in the system will have lower standards of living forced on them; everyone who relies on social security programs will have lower standards of living forced on them because the country simply will not have the money to pay for those programs. This fact has been identified by others more learned than me.

I remind honourable members that one thing that is constantly being put forward is that the major reason for increases in social security costs is the increase in the aged persons section of the program. It is my view that it is not so much the age pensioners who are the major contributors to this rapid increase in costs; it is due to the other programs that are included in the total social security area and are also dealt with in part of the Bill. In a recent article in the Australian newspaper, Mr Russell Schneider pointed out that over a five- year period aged persons' benefits will increase by 64 per cent. He went on to state:

While the total welfare bill over five years rose by 106 per cent, the cost of aged pensions rose by only 64 per cent. The cost of providing benefits to single parents rose by 295 per cent and the cost of unemployment benefits went up by 258 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the honourable member for Wilmot to tie his remarks to the Bill before the House.

—Indeed I will, Mr Deputy Speaker. If you study the Bill, Mr Deputy Speaker, you will find that it relaxes in certain ways the provisions whereby people are able to claim both the unemployment benefit and the supporting parent 's benefit. It is those two sections of the social security bill that are rising at the most rapid rate. I understand that the Minister may well identify unemployed people who he considers are hard done by under the present provisions of the Social Security Act. He may well be able to identify unemployed single parents whom he considers should have greater access to social security. Obviously that is what the Government is trying to correct in this Bill. However , if the effect is to force the social security cost to a point where the economy cannot pay, the Government is not helping those people or any other persons in Australia. The Government is putting those people at a greater disadvantage.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Minister, although I am sure I do not have to do that, of a section of the second reading speech of the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) relating to relaxation of unemployment benefit. It states:

Fourthly, payment of unemployment benefit may be postponed at present for a period of between six and 12 weeks if the applicant's own actions caused his unemployment and he did not have a good and sufficient reason for his actions; if his unemployment is due to his misconduct as a worker; or if he failed without good and sufficient reason to accept a suitable offer of employment.

What the Government is doing in the Bill is removing restrictions on people claiming unemployment benefit and, in fact, giving the Director-General of the Department of Social Security the right to determine what he considers to be appropriate criteria. Naturally that will give a lot of the people who at the moment have some restrictions on their claims for unemployment benefit greater access to that benefit. That can have the final impact only of increasing the total cost of unemployment benefit. We cannot ignore that.

I remind the Minister that in 1981-82 the actual payment for unemployment benefit amounted to $1,224m. That figure has been rising at roughly the rate of $1,000m a year to the point where in 1986-87 the Treasury predicts the total cost of unemployment benefit will be $4,339m. If the Government's proposal under this Bill is to increase those costs even further than those projected by the Treasury, I do not know how this country can continue to provide the money that will be needed.

I understand the Government's compassion in saying that people will be destitute if they have such conditions forced on them because, unfortunately, they have no job. However, if we continue to erode our economy by trying to look after people with money which we do not have and which, in fact, we have to borrow from the money market, I fear that our total social security effort will lead the country into the destitute conditions that are now being experienced in Argentina. I hope the Government will not force that on Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In opening my remarks I thank the honourable member for Wilmot (Mr Burr) for providing his very fine defence of the Government's assets test policy and, indeed, the whole thrust of the Government's legislation in the social welfare field which is, of course, to try to ensure that welfare benefits go to those most in need. In commenting generally on the Opposition's contribution to this debate on the Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill I say that anyone who reads the debate will find it peculiarly illuminating because it illustrates the utter intellectual chaos and disintegration of the Opposition across the whole social welfare field.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition speakers in the debate fell into two groups. Firstly, a number of Opposition speakers did speak to the Bill and its proposals and nearly all of them supported the proposals. I will come back to a few of their specific points because they are deserving of answer. But nearly half the Opposition speakers talked about issues which were not in the Bill at all. They simply seized on the debate as an opportunity to talk about the assets test or, in the case of the leading speakers for the Opposition-the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) and the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), both shadow Ministers-simply repeated what I have called the fly-blown exaggerations of their leader on the issue of the Government's assets test and treatment of the aged.

The first question we should ask ourselves is why the honourable member for Denison and the honourable member for Mackellar hardly addressed themselves to the issues in the Bill and why nearly half the Opposition speakers did not say a word about what was in the Bill. I think the reason for that is that it would make nonsense of their attacks on the Government's social welfare policy as lacking in compassion and concern for the needy in our community because all the measures in this Bill are directed to those most in need in our community. Of course, Opposition speakers really could not afford to talk about that kind of issue. If they did so they would be admitting that in fact the Government has a social welfare policy directed to those most in need.

I will briefly state what the Bill is concerned with. The Bill improves the rent allowances for sickness beneficiaries. The Bill provides a supplementary allowance-that is a rent allowance-for those people who live in and have site payments for their caravans or houseboats. This is a group which had been disadvantaged by the way that the rent allowance worked. The Bill removes anomalies under the current income test arrangements for pensioners and beneficiaries. The Bill provides for treatment of lump sum payments on termination of employment to ensure that all such beneficiaries are fairly treated. The Bill modifies the penalty provisions whereby unemployment benefit was postponed for a period of between six and 12 weeks if unemployment was in some way the result of the beneficiary's own action. The Bill improves the remote area allowance for beneficiaries and pensioners.

The Bill provides incentives for the provision of short term respite accommodation for people cared for in the community. Many aged and handicapped persons prefer to live at home but their relatives need support in the form of a holiday or a break. Too often the only alternative is premature admission to institutional facilities or hospitals. In this Bill we have tried actually to provide for the first time effective incentives for respite care services in hostels. In our later legislation we will be providing the same incentives for nursing homes. That is what the Bill is about. Of course, that is what most honourable members on the other side did not talk about. They preferred the kind of rhetoric which I have called the fly-blown exaggerations about the Government 's policies on the aged. I call them fly-blown because the longer they are left out in the open sunlight of rational discussion the sooner they will be seen to be as gaseous as people increasingly are becoming convinced they are.

I will now take what I consider a typical performance by the honourable member for Mackellar, who was once a sensible advocate of rational policies in the social welfare area. He talked about the income test being applied once again to those over 70 years of age. He did not mention at all in his speech that a single pensioner over 70 years will receive some part of a pension until he earns over $300 a week. He did not mention that a pensioner couple will continue to get some pension until they have other income in excess of $500 a week. That point was entirely left out of the honourable member's speech. Very discreetly the honourable member for Mackellar said:
If their assets exceed certain limits they will lose some of their pensions.

Of course, the honourable member did not mention the limits because those limits are very high and very generous. There is a limit of $70,000 for a single person and $100,000 for a married couple. He did not mention that there was exemption of the family home and that a special $50,000 was added to the threshold for pensioners who do not possess a home; that is, pensioners who rent, live with their relatives or live in a nursing home. Of course, those facts were not mentioned. I mention the distortions concerning the effect of the 35-day rule. The 35-day rule was introduced, again, to ensure cost efficiency of services. The honourable member said:
. . . the 35-day rule introduced for insured hospital patients . . . requires them to leave a hospital after 35 days if they are still in acute care.

I think the whole statement is confused, but certainly there is no such requirement. If such patients are still in need of acute care they are covered by nearly all the insurance companies in this country. If they are in need of nursing home care they are still covered for that treatment in the private hospital at a slightly lower rate.

Again, there was an attack on our policy as regards changes in hostel funding. The honourable member for Mackellar mentioned a problem that has arisen out of that policy. What he forgot to tell the House is that, as a result of those changes, we have increased personal care subsidies and hostel care subsidies this year, 1983-84, by $4.5m. In a full year that figure will be over $11m. But that fact, of course, was left out. We then heard the nonsense about Medicare's effect on the consumer price index. Let me say that all people on fixed incomes will benefit greatly from our ability to keep the CPI down and from the effects of that flowing through the community in the form of lower prices. Nobody will benefit more from that than pensioners and others on fixed incomes. The Government has already indicated that if there is unfairness as a result of the working of Medicare on the CPI it will be addressed during Budget considerations . I think that, increasingly, the Australian people will come to see such exaggerations for what they are. Increasingly they will be given the facts about the welfare policy of this Government.

Let me just say a little about the serious points which were raised by members on both sides of the House. First, the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) was somewhat concerned about the guidelines in relation to de facto relationships. This Government is very much aware of the need for sensitivity in investigating whether de facto relationships exist. Last year, the Department of Social Security issued national guidelines for investigating de facto relationships. We made those guidelines publicly available. We are reviewing the guidelines again in the light of experience with their administration and of comments provided by organisations and individuals in the community in order to ensure the most appropriate balance is struck between the need for proper administration and the rights of clients affected. So I can assure the honourable member for Lowe that his concern is well in hand.

The honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) raised a fundamental issue. It is the sort of fundamental issue relating to social welfare that I think is really worth discussing on both sides of the House. It concerns the treatment of the family and the individual and the implications that has for spouses, particularly of course for women, and whether, in fact, we should continue a social welfare policy which is based essentially on the family unit or whether we should adopt a policy similar to the policy we have in regard to taxation, that is, to treat welfare beneficiaries and recipients on an individual basis. That is a very important question and it is thoroughly worth canvassing. I must say that, as usual, the honourable member for Sturt contributed important and worthwhile considerations to this debate. We will certainly continue to keep that issue under review. His comments have been noted and as we continue our reviews of social welfare policy they will be kept in mind.

There has been some protest on the other side of the House about our provisions for making the penalty sanctions regarding the unemployment benefit slightly more flexible. The real problem is that at the moment if such a sanction is applied it has to be for at least six weeks' duration. There is no flexibility between no weeks and six weeks. The six-week penalty for, say, a man with three children may involve something like $1,000 in unemployment benefit. That man would already have lost his job, perhaps for some minor misdemeanour. Then, on top of that, a penalty of $1,000 would be imposed. All we are saying in this legislation is that the Director-General should have a little more flexibility. At the moment he can make a judgement involving a period from six to 12 weeks. We are simply saying that we believe it is appropriate for him to have a somewhat greater flexibility in looking at individual cases. That is the purpose of that change.

The honourable member for Mackellar, in about the only remarks he addressed to the Bill itself, raised with me the problem regarding respite care. He asked why we provide a $10 a week subsidy to people who use hostels for less than 14 days for respite care and a $50 payment to those who use them for 15 days or more. It is a fairly complicated issue but the basis of it is very simple. On the evidence we have, those persons using respite care for a period of 14 days or less have very little need for extra services. That is, they are very much ordinary hostel care patients, whereas the bulk of the patients who use hostels for longer terms mostly appear to need treatment at the level of the personal care subsidy which, as the honourable member knows, is structured at $50 a day. So the basic reason for making that decision was that in the case of short term users we equated the subsidy to the hostel care subsidy of $10 a week, whereas in the case of longer term respite care we equated it with the personal care subsidy of $50 a week.

We admit that this proposal is new and we will monitor it carefully to see its effects. It is designed very much to provide incentives to people who run hostels to take on respite care because it will contribute so much to enable people to stay in the community in the knowledge that they also have respite care to fall back on for short periods. However, we will certainly monitor the assumption we made that people using hostels for short periods are mostly in need of a fairly low level of care and that people using them for longer periods require a higher level of care.

The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) raised an issue in relation to the compensation case of Mrs Owen. We have followed that through. The case was handled by the Department of Defence in Melbourne as a result of the honourable member raising the matter. The Commissioner for Employees' Compensation in Canberra will take over the processing of Mrs Owen's case. The honourable member will be contacted about that matter shortly.

The honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) raised the question of extending the defence service homes insurance scheme to all veterans and serving members eligible for defence service home loans whether or not they had such a loan. The Government will review the position and give consideration to that suggestion. I thank the honourable member for Grayndler for bringing the point to the Government's attention.

The honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) when talking about repatriation matters, in fact, wandered into the area of the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill 1984 which deals with delays in the repatriation determination system. That Bill, which was introduced into the Senate on 29 May, has not reached this House yet. But I certainly welcome very much the honourable member' s support for the measure in advance of its arriving in this House.

The honourable member for Mackellar concluded his speech by saying that he was going to bring the Government to account in relation to its failure to be a compassionate government, caring for the less well off in our society. Let me say that I think this measure is but one of a number of measures which clearly indicate the Government's compassion and concern for the less well off in this society. As we have indicated, it will be followed by further extensions of the pension rent allowance for a particularly hard pressed group of pensioners. It will be followed by adjustments to the weekly rate of pension to get it to the level of the 25 per cent of average weekly earnings which we have promised. It will be followed by a community care program for the aged. The Opposition will see all of those policies developed in the next six months. I am very confident indeed that the development of those policies will certainly answer the charges of the honourable member for Mackellar. When we finally face the electorate, I have no doubt at all that the performance of the Government in this area will be seen as both compassionate and caring.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has not been convinced by the Government in the arguments it has put forward in favour of clause 41 of the Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill. Clause 41 of the Bill amends section 120, sub-section (1) and (2), of the Social Security Act, which provides for unemployment benefits to be postponed for a minimum period of six to 12 weeks under certain circumstances. So the present situation is that if a person becomes unemployed due either directly or indirectly to his voluntary act, which in the opinion of the Director-General was without good or sufficient reason; or if that person's unemployment is due to his misconduct as a worker; or if that person has refused or failed without good and sufficient reason to accept an offer of employment which the Director-General considers to be suitable-in other words, if that person has failed a work test; or if in the opinion of the Director-General the person is a seasonal or intermittent worker, then the present Act requires that he not be given unemployment benefits for a minimum of six weeks and up to 12 weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) representing the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) has said that the Government wishes to remove the restriction of six weeks before the unemployment benefit is payable. I do not think it is unreasonable for the Opposition to question this. If there is a discretion on the part of the Director-General we would see it being increasingly used. We believe that the reasons that have to be present for there to be a six-week delay-the four reasons I have quoted-are perfectly reasonable. Therefore, we intend to vote against this clause of the Bill.
Question put:
That clause 41 be agreed to.
